member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.IArithmeticProvider`1
member.summary: Defines methods for performing arithmetic operations on value types where the offset and scale types are the same as the original type.
member.typeparam: The type on which to perform the operations.
member.remarks: Most value types that support arithmetic operations fall into this category; namely, types where the offset and scale type are the same as the original type. For example, the result of multiplying two integers is another integer, and the result of subtracting two bytes is another byte.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.IArithmeticProvider`3
member.summary: Defines methods for performing arithmetic operations on value types.
member.typeparam: The type on which to perform the operations.
The type of the offsetting operand for offsetting operations.
The type of the scaling operand for scaling operations.
member.remarks: This interface is a combination of all arithmetic interfaces. It includes support for adding, subtracting, multiplying, dividing, and perfomring signed arithmetic. Certain types may not support all operations exposed by this interface. Check the value in the returned by for the list of supported capabilities for the current type.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.BatchJobInfo.ReplaceBatchDateTime(System.String,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Substitutes into a string according to the pattern specified.
member.param: The string containing the pattern(s) to substitute.
An optional to apply to prior to formatting.
member.returns: The modified string.
member.remarks: Only valid formatting sequences are considered. Anything that does not match a standard sequence is ignored. (Essentially, everything between braces is passed as the format string to .) The '{' and '}' characters, when not used as the pattern start/end indicators, must be escaped by doubling them ("{{" and "}}", respectively).
member.example: If is January 2, 2008, 1:00:00 PM, the following string "{yyyy} MMyyyy {yo dd-HH}" becomes: "2008 MMyyyy 1o 02-13" when calling .

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.ByteOrder
member.content: Contains method permutations for changing byte orderings.
member.summary: Contains methods for modifying the byte order of integer values.

remarks.para: This class provides functions for changing the ordering of bytes with in integral values. Most commonly (though not always), byte ordering is significant when considering the endianness of the CPU architecture running the program.

(Note: in the vast majority of cases, it is desireable to write programs that are not sensitive to the underlying endianness of the machine on which they run, as it can be difficult to maintain and prone to errors to try to support both configurations. However, there are some cases when such code is inevitable, and in these cases, the functions in can be useful.)

"Endianness" refers to the convention used to interpret the bytes making up a data word in computer memory; specifically, the ordering of these bytes. Big-endian systems store the most significant byte of a word in the smallest address and the least significant byte in the largest address. Little-endian systems, in contrast, store the least significant byte in the smallest address and the most significant byte in the largest address.

Consider the following example of storing the 32-bit integer 0x0A0B0C0D in memory:
On a big-endian system, the following table shows how the integer will be laid out in memory:
Address Value
a 0A
a + 10B
a + 20C
a + 30D
In contrast, on a little-endian system, the same integer will be laid out as follows:
Address Value
a 0D
a + 10C
a + 20B
a + 30A

The functions in the class facilitate transforming back and forth between little-, big-, and native byte ordering. Native byte ordering is defined as the endianness of the CPU executing the current process. When using a function to transform the byte order of a value, the actual ordering of the bytes in memory may or may not change, depending on the current and target endianness. For example, the function is a no-op on a little-endian CPU.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ByteOrder.GetEndianness(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the endianness of the current CPU based on the memory layout of the integer value 0x00000001 or 0x01000000.,
member.param: The value to check; should be either 0x00000001 or 0x01000000.
member.returns: The of the system.
member.remarks: This method checks the value of the least-significant byte to determine whether the system is little or big-endian. The behavior of this function is undefined if is not either 0x00000001 or 0x01000000.

member.summary: A private member.

member.summary: A member that is accessible to any class within the same assembly.

member.summary: A member that is accessible within the family of its class and derived classes.

member.summary: A member that is accessible within its class, and derived classes in the same assembly.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.AccessAttributes.FamilyOrAssembly

member.summary: Defines modifier attributes for classes and members.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.None
member.summary: Indicates that no attributes have been specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Abstract
member.summary: Indicate that a class is intended only to be a base class of other classes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Const
member.summary: Specify that the value of the field or the local variable cannot be modified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Extern
member.summary: Indicates that the method is implemented externally.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Final
member.summary: Sepecifies that a member cannot be overridden.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.New
member.summary: Hides an inherited member from a base class member.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Override
member.summary: Provides a new implementation of a virtual member inherited from a base class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Partial
member.summary: Defines partial classes, structs, and methods throughout the same assembly.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.ReadOnly
member.summary: Declares a field that can only be assigned values as part of the declaration or in a constructor in the same class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Sealed
member.summary: Sepecifies that a class cannot be inherited.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Static
member.summary: Declares a member that belongs to the type itself instead of to a specific object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Unsafe
member.summary: Declares an unsafe context.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Virtual
member.summary: Declares a method or an accessor whose implementation can be changed by an overriding member in a derived class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CodeDom.ModifierAttributes.Volatile
member.summary: Indicates that a field can be modified in the program by something such as the operating system, the hardware, or a concurrently executing thread.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.ArrayTExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods for arrays of objects.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ArrayTExtensions.BinarySearch``1(``0[],``0)
member.summary: Searches an entire one-dimensional sorted array for a value.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the array.
member.param: The sorted, one-dimensional array to search.
The value to search for.
member.returns: The index of the specified value in the specified array, if value is found. If value is not found and value is less than one or more elements in array, a negative number which is the bitwise complement of the index of the first element that is larger than value. If value is not found and value is greater than any of the elements in array, a negative number which is the bitwise complement of (the index of the last element plus 1).

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ArrayTExtensions.BinarySearch``1(``0[],``0,System.Collections.Generic.IComparer{``0})
member.summary: Searches an entire one-dimensional sorted array for a value using the specified .
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the array.
member.param: The sorted, one-dimensional array to search.
The value to search for.
The to use when comparing items in the array.
member.returns: The index of the specified value in the specified array, if value is found. If value is not found and value is less than one or more elements in array, a negative number which is the bitwise complement of the index of the first element that is larger than value. If value is not found and value is greater than any of the elements in array, a negative number which is the bitwise complement of (the index of the last element plus 1).

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ArrayTExtensions.Contains``1(``0[],``0)
member.summary: Determines whether an array contains a specified element by using the default equality comparer.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the array.
member.param: The array to search.
The object to locate in the array. The value can be null for reference types.
member.returns: true if the array contains the specified value; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: The array is searched forward starting at the first element and ending at the last element.
This method is more efficient than when used on arrays due to better optimized IL instructions.
This method performs a linear search; therefore, this method is an O(n) operation, where n is the length of the array.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ArrayTExtensions.Contains``1(``0[],``0,System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{``0})

remarks.para: The array is searched forward starting at the first element and ending at the last element.
This method is more efficient than when used on arrays due to better optimized IL instructions.
This method performs a linear search; therefore, this method is an O(n) operation, where n is the length of the array.

remarks.para: You can also use the property to add new elements by setting the value of a key that does not exist in the ; for example, myCollection[myKey] = myValue. However, if the specified key already exists in the , setting the property overwrites the old value. In contrast, the method throws an exception if a value with the specified key already exists.

If the property value already equals the capacity, the capacity of the is increased by automatically reallocating the internal array, and the existing elements are copied to the new array before the new element is added.
Neither the key nor value can be null.
If is less than the capacity, this method approaches an O(1) operation. If the capacity must be increased to accommodate the new element, this method becomes an O(n) operation, where n is .

When this method returns, contains the value associated with the specified key, if the key is found; otherwise, the default value for the type of the value parameter. This parameter is passed uninitialized.

remarks.para: This method combines the functionality of the method and the property.
If the key is not found, then the value parameter gets the appropriate default value for the type ; for example, 0 (zero) for integer types, false for types, and null for reference types.
Use the method if your code frequently attempts to access keys that are not in the dictionary. Using this method is more efficient than catching the thrown by the property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Collections.TreeEnumerator`1.MoveNext
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, advances the enumerator to the next node in the tree.
member.returns: true if the enumerator was successfully advanced to the next node; false if the enumerator has passed the end of the tree.

remarks.para: After an enumerator is created or after the Reset method is called, an enumerator is positioned before the first element of the collection, and the first call to the MoveNext method moves the enumerator over the first element of the collection.

If passes the end of the collection, the enumerator is positioned after the last element in the collection and returns false. When the enumerator is at this position, subsequent calls to return false until is called.

An enumerator remains valid as long as the tree remains unchanged. If changes are made to the tree, such as adding, modifying, or deleting nodes, the enumerator is irrecoverably invalidated and the next call to or throws an .

remarks.para: An enumerator remains valid as long as the tree remains unchanged. If changes are made to the tree, such as adding, modifying, or deleting nodes, the enumerator is irrecoverably invalidated and the next call to or throws an .

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Collections.DepthFirstTreeEnumerator`1.#ctor(Microsoft.BI.Common.Collections.ITreeNode{`0})
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class that will be used to enumerate the specified .
member.param: The to be enumerated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Collections.DepthFirstTreeEnumerator`1.MoveNext
member.summary: Advances the enumerator to the next node in the tree.
member.returns: true if the enumerator was successfully advanced to the next node; false if the enumerator has passed the end of the tree.

remarks.para: The next node is chosen according to the depth-first search (DFS) algorithm. In DFS, each node is explored as far as possible before backtracking to a node that has not yet been fully explored. The search continues until the goal is reached or all nodes have been fully processed.

After an enumerator is created or after the method is called, an enumerator is positioned before the first element of the collection, and the first call to the method moves the enumerator over the first element of the collection.

If passes the end of the collection, the enumerator is positioned after the last element in the collection and returns false. When the enumerator is at this position, subsequent calls to return false until is called.

An enumerator remains valid as long as the tree remains unchanged. If changes are made to the tree, such as adding, modifying, or deleting nodes, the enumerator is irrecoverably invalidated and the next call to or throws an .

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.cstring
member.summary: Contains several functions to manipulate strings and arrays.
member.remarks: These methods are based on methods of the same name defined in string.h in c++.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.cstring.memcmp(System.Void*,System.Void*,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Compares two blocks of memory for equality.
member.param: A pointer to the first block of memory to compare.
A pointer to the second block of memory to compare.
The number of bytes to compare.
member.returns: A value less than 0 if the first byte that does not match in both memory blocks has a lesser value in than in ; a value greater than 0 if the first byte that does not match in both memory blocks has a greater value in than in ; otherwise, 0.

remarks.para: This method compares the first bytes of the block of memory pointed to by to the first bytes of the block of memory pointed to by , returning zero if they all match or a value different from zero representing which is greater if not.
Note that, unlike strcmp, this function does not stop comparing after finding a null character.

Contrast to , which returns a boolean value indicating whether two blocks of memory are different. This method is less performant than , and should only be used when the relative value between the two blocks of memory is required.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.cstring.WordwiseMemoryCompare(System.UInt64*,System.UInt64*,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Compares memory one word at a time.
member.param: A pointer to the first block of memory to compare.
A pointer to the second block of memory to compare.
The number of words to compare.
member.returns: A value less than 0 if the first byte that does not match in both memory blocks has a lesser value in than in ; a value greater than 0 if the first byte that does not match in both memory blocks has a greater value in than in ; otherwise, 0.

remarks.para: This method compares blocks of memory 1 word (8 bytes) at a time. It has no special alignment requirements. must be greater than or equal to 8.
If a difference is found, the result is defined as the first difference between the byte values at the same offset in each block of memory, regardless of how many differences there are in total.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.cstring.BytewiseMemoryCompare(System.Byte*,System.Byte*,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Compares memory one byte at a time.
member.param: A pointer to the first block of memory to compare.
A pointer to the second block of memory to compare.
The number of bytes to compare.
member.returns: A value less than 0 if the first byte that does not match in both memory blocks has a lesser value in than in ; a value greater than 0 if the first byte that does not match in both memory blocks has a greater value in than in ; otherwise, 0.

remarks.para: This method compares blocks of memory 1 byte at a time. It has no special alignment requirements.
If a difference is found, the result is defined as the first difference between the byte values at the same offset in each block of memory, regardless of how many differences there are in total.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.cstring.memeq(System.Void*,System.Void*,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Compares two blocks of memory for equality.
member.param: A pointer to the first block of memory to compare.
A pointer to the second block of memory to compare.
The number of bytes to compare.
member.returns: true if the block of memory pointed to by and the block of memory pointed to by are equal; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: This method compares the first bytes of the block of memory pointed to by to the first bytes of the block of memory pointed to by , returning true if they all match or false if not.
Note that, unlike strcmp, this function does not stop comparing after finding a null character.

Contrast to , which returns an integer value indicating the difference between the first differing byte in two blocks of memory. This method is slightly more performant than and should be used when testing for equality alone.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.cstring.memcpy(System.Void*,System.Void*,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Copies the values of bytes from the location pointed by directly to the memory block pointed by . and may not overlap.
member.param: Pointer to the destination array where the content is to be copied.
Pointer to the source of data to be copied.
Number of bytes to copy.
member.returns: A pointer to the destination ().

remarks.para: The underlying type of the objects pointed by both the source and destination pointers are irrelevant for this function; the result is a binary copy of the data.
The function does not check for any terminating null character in source - it always copies exactly bytes.
To avoid overflows, the size of the arrays pointed by both the and parameters shall be at least bytes, and should not overlap (for overlapping memory blocks, memmove is a safer approach).
If and overlap, the behavior of this method is undefined. Use if it is possible for and to overlap.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.cstring.memchr(System.Void*,System.Byte,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Searches within the first bytes of the block of memory pointed to by for the first occurence of and returns a pointer to it.
member.param: A pointer to the block of memory where the search is performed.
The value to search for.
The number of bytes to search.
member.returns: A pointer to the first occurence of in the block of memory pointed to by , or null if not found.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.cstring.memchr(System.Char*,System.Char,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Searches within the first characters of the block of memory pointed to by for the first occurence of and returns a pointer to it.
member.param: A pointer to the block of memory where the search is performed.
The value to search for.
The number of characters to search.
member.returns: A pointer to the first occurence of in the block of memory pointed to by , or null if not found.

remarks.para: This method considers the alignment of - a character will only be considered a match if it has the same alignment as . For example, the following byte sequence would not be considered a match, even though it does contain a sequence of two bytes that match the bytes of the character 'a' (0x0061): 0x00006100.
If is not aligned evenly (the address is not even), this method will have significantly worse performance than if it is.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.CSharp.CSharpLexer.PendingPosition
member.summary: For strings, the default lexing behavior for setting position to the last token does't work well. Setting PendingPosition will cause the next call to Scan() to set the position to the position specified instead of the default behavior. This should generally be used to merge the beginning of the string with the final quote mark to get the right final position.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.CSharp.CSharpTypeBinder.LoadDll(System.String)
member.summary: Loads an assembly from the specified path, or the assembly with the given name from the GAC.
member.param: The path to an assembly - or - the name of an assembly in the GAC.
member.returns: The loaded object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.CSharp.CSharpTypeBinder.LoadDll(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Loads an assembly from the specified path, or the assembly with the given name from the GAC.
member.param: The path to an assembly - or - the name of an assembly in the GAC.
The actual path to the assembly that was loaded. This is primarily used when loading assemblies from the GAC.
member.returns: The loaded object.
member.remarks:
This method supports two different ways to load assmeblies:
Type Behavior
Local path
Attempts to load the assembly by file name from the local disk. In this case, will return the same value as .
GAC (Global Assembly Cache)
Attempts to load the assembly by name from the GAC. In this case, will be resolved to the final path on disk in which the GAC'd DLL resides.
GAC assembly loading currently only works reliably with builtin .NET assemblies. It is possible to load others, but if the is greater than the current .NET version, loading won't work.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.DataStore.IBatch.Commit
member.summary: Commits all pending batch operations.

remarks.para: If any operation results in an exception, the exception will be propagated to the caller. Any operations that have already completed will not be rolled back, and any pending operations will not be performed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.DataStore.IDataStore
member.summary: Represents an untyped data store which can be read from and written to.

remarks.para: The interface represents an untyped data store from which data can be read and to which data can be written. The store supports namespacing, allowing the smae key to be present in the store as long as it has a different namespace, and allowing for organization of data by access type (as objects or columns). The store also supports expiring data via TTL.

Generally, consumers are not expected to interact with the data store directly via the methods on this interface. Instead, they should use and to get a data view which facilitates easier interaction with the store.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.DataStore.IDataStore.BeginBatch
member.summary: Returns an for running one or more operations in a batch.
member.returns: A for running one or more operations in a batch.
member.exception: The store implementation does not support batching.

remarks.para: A batch is a unit of work performed in the store that contains potentially several operations in a single command. Unlike a transaction, these operations do not necessarily need to be executed according to ACID properties. Rather, batches provide a way to amoritize the cost of communication between the store and the consumer by combining many operations into a single call to and from the store.
An implementer that does not support batching should throw a when this method is called.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.DataStore.IDataStore.BeginTransaction
member.summary: Begins a store transaction where all operations are committed atomically.
member.returns: An instance for managing the transaction.
member.exception: The store implementation does not support transactions.

remarks.para: A transaction is a unit of work performed the store that is treated in a coherent and reliable way independent of other transactions. Transactions are atomic, consistent, isolated, and durable (ACID). Transactions are "all-or-nothing", meaning that each operation performed in the store must either complete in its entirety or have no effect whatsoever.
An implementer that does not support transactions should throw a when this method is called.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.DataStore.IKeyValueStoreView`2.BeginBatch
member.summary: Returns an for running one or more operations in a batch.
member.returns: A for running one or more operations in a batch.
member.exception: The store implementation does not support batching.

remarks.para: A batch is a unit of work performed in the store that contains potentially several operations in a single command. Unlike a transaction, these operations do not necessarily need to be executed according to ACID properties. Rather, batches provide a way to amoritize the cost of communication between the store and the consumer by combining many operations into a single call to and from the store.
An implementer that does not support batching should throw a when this method is called.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.DataStore.IKeyValueStoreView`2.BeginTransaction
member.summary: Begins a store transaction where all operations are committed atomically.
member.returns: An instance for managing the transaction.
member.exception: The store implementation does not support transactions.

remarks.para: A transaction is a unit of work performed the store that is treated in a coherent and reliable way independent of other transactions. Transactions are atomic, consistent, isolated, and durable (ACID). Transactions are "all-or-nothing", meaning that each operation performed in the store must either complete in its entirety or have no effect whatsoever.
An implementer that does not support transactions should throw a when this method is called.

member.summary: Commits all pending transaction operations.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.DateTimeDeltaExtensions.Truncate(System.DateTime,System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Truncate a to the specified resolution, in ticks.
member.param: The to truncate.
The resolution of the truncation (ie., TimeSpan.TicksPerHour to truncate to the nearest hour).
The offset within the resolution to truncate to (ie., resolution of TimeSpan.TicksPerHour and alignment of TimeSpan.TicksPerMinute to truncate to the nearest first minute of the hour).
member.returns: The truncated .
member.remarks: Values for that are not between 0 and act as the euclidean division remainder of alignment divided by resolution. For example, if is 60, then values of -50, 10, 70, etc would all produce the same result.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.DateTimeDeltaExtensions.Truncate(System.DateTime,System.TimeSpan,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Truncate a to the specified resolution.
member.param: The to truncate.
The resolution of the truncation (ie., TimeSpan.FromHours(1) to truncate to the nearest hour).
The offset within the resolution to ceiling to (ie., resolution of TimeSpan.FromHours(1) and alignment of TimeSpan.FromMinutes(1) to ceiling to the nearest first minute of the hour).
member.returns: The truncated .
member.remarks: Values for that are not between 0 and act as the euclidean division remainder of alignment divided by resolution. For example, if is 01:00, then values of -00:50, 00:10, 01:10, etc would all produce the same result.

member.summary: Replaces format specifiers in with the specified value.
member.param: The string containing the format specifiers to replace.
The value to replace.
member.returns: with all format specifiers replaced by .
member.exception: contains an invalid pattern (see remarks for details).

remarks.para: format specifiers must be delimited on either side by the pattern start and pattern end characters, '{' and '}', respectively. For example, "{yyyy}/{MM}/{dd}" or "{yyyy/MM/dd}".

Format specifier replacement works in exactly the same way as normal pattern replacement in and associated overrides. However, format specifiers will only be replaced when delimited in a pattern via the pattern start and end characters; any format specifier outside these delimiters will be copied literally to the output without replacement.
In order to escape the pattern start or end characters, place two in a sequence; for example, "{{yyyy}}".

The pattern start and end characters must be balanced within . Furthermore, they cannot be nested (there may only be one active pattern at once). Violations to either of these conditions will result in a being thrown.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.DateTimeRange
member.summary: Represents a range of time, typically expressed as two values or a value and a value.

remarks.para: As a is based on at least one value, it can represent ranges of dates and times with values starting or ending between from 00:00:00 (midnight), January 1, 0001 Anno Domini (Common Era) through 11:59:59 P.M., December 31st, 9999 A.D. (C.E.) in the Gregorian calendar, just like values.
A calculation using a structure, such as or , does not modify the value of the structure. Instead, the calculation returns a new structure whose value is the result of the calculation.
A differs from a or a in that a represents an instant in time and a represents a time interval, whereas a represents both an instant in time and a time interval starting at that instant in time.

You can add or subtract a time interval from the beginning or end of a object. Time intervals can be negative or positive, can be expressed in units such as ticks or seconds, or can be expressed as a object.
The interval expressed by the is inclusive at the start and exclusive at the end.

member.summary: Returns a new that adds the value of the specified to the range in this instance.
member.param: A positive or negative time interval.
member.returns: An object whose value is the sum of the date, time, and range represented by this instance and the time interval represented by .
member.exception: The resulting value's property is less than , greater than , or less than this value's property.

remarks.para: The value specified by is added to the end of the range represented by this instance. If is positive, the new range's will be longer than the current instance; if it is negative, the new range's will be shorter than the current instance.
You can use the method to add more than one kind of time interval (days, hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds) in a single operation.
The method takes into account leap years and the number of days in a month when performing date arithmetic.
This method does not change the value of the . Instead, it returns a new whose value is the result of this operation.

member.remarks: For generic types, the generic type parameter must match the original type's generic type parameter or else accessing the type's members will fail at runtime. This method replaces generic type definitions from other assemblies with the generic type of the type that we are generating.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Dynamic.DynamicContractTypeBuilder.GetTypeName(System.Type)
member.summary: Gets the name of the dynamic type to generate based on the target type.
member.param: The target type.
member.returns: The name of the dynamically-generated type.

remarks.para: For non-generic types, the generated name is simply <>__DynamicContracts. prepended to the target type's full name.

For generic types, the generated name is the same as for non-generic types, with the addition of a generic type suffix. The generic type suffix includes the names of each type in the generic arguments of . For reference types, the will reuse an existing dynamic type, as the generated code is exactly the same for all reference types. It will create a new dynamic type for each generic instance with different value type parameters. This behavior mirrors the behavior of the C# JIT compiler.

remarks.para: Returns a statically-typed object instance as a dynamic object. Members will be accessed at runtime via reflection.

and are used to control which members are visible in the dynamic object. The default behavior is that all publicly-visible fields, properties, and members can be accessed dynamically. By providing different , you can include private members and/or exclude public members. By providing different , you can change the members that are visible (for example, by excluding methods, you will only see public properties and fields).

member.summary: Gets the value of the property or field with the specified name from the .
member.param: The instance in which to get the value.
The name of the field or property whose value to get.
member.returns: The value of the property.
member.exception: A binding error was thrown when attempting to get the value of the member.

remarks.para: If does not contain a member with name , a will be thrown.
If does contain a member with name , but it is not readable as a field or property for some reason (it is a write-only property or is a method, for example), a will be thrown.

If contains a dotted list of members ("A.B.C"), members will be resolved one member name at a time. For example, if the requested member name is "A.B.C", this method will look for a member named "A" on , then for a member named "B" on the result, and finally for a member named "C" on that result.

If contains a dotted list of members ("A.B.C"), members will be resolved one member name at a time. For example, if the requested member name is "A.B.C", this method will look for a member named "A" on , then for a member named "B" on the result, and finally set the value of a member named "C" on that result.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Enum`1.GetName(`0)
member.summary: Retrieves the name of the constant that has the specified value.
member.param: The enumerated constant value.
member.returns: A string containing the name of the enumerated constant in whose value is , or null if no such constant is found.
member.remarks: If multiple enumeration members have the same underlying value, the method guarantees that it will return the name of one of those enumeration members. However, it does not guarantee that it will always return the name of the same enumeration member. As a result, when multiple enumeration members have the same value, your application code should never depend on the method returning a particular member's name.

member.summary: Retrieves an array of the names of the constants in the enumeration.
member.returns: A string array of the names of the constants in .

member.summary: Returns the underlying type of the specified enumeration.
member.returns: The underlying type of .
member.remarks: The structure enables values to be represented as named constants. The data type of the enumeration's values is known as its underlying type. For example, the underlying type of the enumeration, which consists of constants that represent each day of the week (, , and so on), is .

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Enum`1.GetValues
member.summary: Retrieves an array of the values in a specified enumeration.
member.returns: An array that contains the values in .

remarks.para: The elements of the array are sorted by the binary values of the enumeration constants (that is, by their unsigned magnitude).

The method returns an array that contains a value for each member of the enumeration. If multiple members have the same value, the returned array includes duplicate values. In this case, calling the method with each value in the returned array does not restore the unique names assigned to members that have duplicate values. To retrieve all the names of enumeration members successfully, call the method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Enum`1.IsDefined(System.String)
member.summary: Returns an indication whether a constant with a specified value exists in a specified enumeration.
member.param: The name of a constant in .
member.returns: true if a constant in has a value equal to ; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: This method is case-sensitive.

If the constants in define a set of bit fields and contains the names of multiple bit fields, the method returns false. In other words, for enumerations that define a set of bit fields, the method determines only whether a single bit field belongs to the enumeration. To determine whether multiple bit fields are set in an enumeration type that is tagged with the attribute, you can call the method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Enum`1.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of the name or numeric value of one or more enumerated constants to an equivalent enumerated object.
member.param: A string containing the name or value to convert.
member.returns: An enumeration value of type whose value is represented by .
member.exception: is not an , -or- is either an empty string or contains only white space, -or- is a name, but not one of the named constants defined for the enumeration.
is outside the range of the underlying type of .

remarks.para: The parameter contains the string representation of an enumeration member's underlying value or named constant, or a list of named constants delimited by commas (,). One or more blank spaces can precede or follow each value, name, or comma in value. If value is a list, the return value is the value of the specified names combined with a bitwise OR operation.

If value is a name that does not correspond to a named constant of , the method throws an . If value is the string representation of an integer that does not represent an underlying value of the enumeration, the method returns an enumeration member whose underlying value is value converted to an integral type. If this behavior is undesirable, call the method to ensure that a particular string representation of an integer is actually a member of .

member.summary: Converts the specified value to an enumeration member.
member.typeparam: The underlying type of the enum.
member.param: The value to convert to an enumeration member.
member.returns: An instance of the enumeration set to .
member.remarks: The method converts value to an enumeration member whose underlying value is . Note that the conversion succeeds even if value is outside the bounds of members. To ensure that value is a valid underlying value of the enumeration, pass it to the method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Enum`1.TryParse(System.String,`0@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of the name or numeric value of one or more enumerated constants to an equivalent enumerated object. The return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded.
member.param: The string representaiton of the enumeration name or underlying value to convert.

When this method returns, contains an object of type whose value is represented by if the parse operation succeeds. If the parse operation fails, contains the default value of the underlying type of . Note that this value need not be a member of the enumeration. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if the parameter was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: is identical to the method, except that instead of throwing an exception, it returns false if the conversion fails. It eliminates the need for exception handling when parsing the string representation of an enumeration value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Hashing.Crc32Algorithm
member.summary: Represents a CRC-32 algorithm implementation.

remarks.para: Cyclic redundancy checks are a well-defined process for computing an approximation of the validity of data. However, there are many 'parameters' to the computation. This class encapsulates these parameters into a single unit that controls the behavior of a .

The parameters of a CRC-32 hashing algorithm are as follows:
Parameter Definition
Width The number of bits in the algorithm (always 32 for CRC-32).
Polynomial The polynomial representing the binary coefficients used in the polynomnial division of the CRC algorithm. This polynomial is always expressed in its non-reflected form, even for algorithms that use reflected computation.
Init The initial value of the register when the algorithm starts.
Reflected Whether the algorithm should use reflected processing path (bit 0 is MSB) or the normal processing path (bit 0 is LSB). This parameter corresponds to the REFIN and REFOUT parameters sometimes used to describe CRC algorithms.
XorOut The value to XOR the final CRC result with before returning.

member.summary: The definition of the CRC-32 (PKZIP) algorithm.
member.remarks:
The parameters of this algorithm are:
ParameterValue
Polynomial0x04c11db7
Init 0xffffffff
Reflected true
XorOut 0xffffffff

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarArchiveReader
member.summary: Provides access to the contents of a Tape ARchive (TAR) file.
member.remarks: Implements the POSIX.1-1988 ustar standard. Doesn't handle any sort of tar extensions beyond the standard.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarArchiveReader.BaseDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the directory into which files extracted from the archive should be placed.
member.remarks: All files extracted from the archive will be placed into this folder. Files in the archive that contain directory information will be created inside this directory with the directory structure specified in the archive. The default value is the current directory. Setting this value to null will likewise use the current directory.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarArchiveReader.Overwrite
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether files extracted from the archive should overwrite files with the same name on the local filesystem.
member.remarks: If true, then files extracted from the archive will overwrite any files in the destination location with the same name. If false, any files that already exist in the destination will not be overwritten. The default value is false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarArchiveReader.PreserveAbsoluteFileNames
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to preserve absolute file names as is.
member.remarks: If true, absolute file names will be preserved on extraction. WARNING - this can be very dangerous, as it can cause extraction to overwrite files in unexpected places on the system. If false, all files that are extracted will be placed inside of . The default value is false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarArchiveReader.PreserveModificationTime
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to extract modification time for files extracted from the archive.
member.remarks: If true, the modification time of the file when extracted will be set to the time in the archive. If false, the modification time will be when the file was extracted from the archive. The default value is true.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader
member.summary: Represents a single 512-byte TAR header.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.name
member.summary: The name of the file.
member.remarks: The file's path name is created using this field, or by using this field in connection with the field. If the field is included, the name of the file is 'prefix/name'. This field is null-terminated unless every character is non-null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.mode
member.summary: The mode of the file.
member.remarks: Provides 9 bits for file permissions and 3 bits for SUID, SGID, and SVTX modes. All values for this field are in octal. During a read operation, the designated mode bits are ignored if the user does not have equal (or higher) permissions or if the modes are not supported. Numeric fields are terminated with a space and a null byte.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.uid
member.summary: The user ID of the file.
member.remarks: Extracted from the corresponding archive fields unless a user with appropriate privileges restores the file. In that case, the field value is extracted from the password and group files instead. Numeric fields are terminated with a space and a null byte.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.gid
member.summary: The group ID of the file.
member.remarks: Extracted from the corresponding archive fields unless a user with appropriate privileges restores the file. In that case, the field value is extracted from the password and group files instead. Numeric fields are terminated with a space and a null byte.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.size
member.summary: The size of the file.
member.remarks: Value is 0 when the typeflag field is set to LNKTYPE. This field is terminated with a space only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.mtime
member.summary: The last modified time of the file.
member.remarks: Value is obtained from the modification-time field of the stat subroutine. This field is terminated with a space only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.cksum
member.summary: The checksum of the header.
member.remarks: On calculation, the sum of all bytes in the header structure are treated as spaces. Each unsigned byte is added to an unsigned integer (initialized to 0) with at least 17-bits precision. Numeric fields are terminated with a space and a null byte.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.typeflag
member.summary: The type flag of the file.
member.remarks: Numeric fields are terminated with a space and a null byte.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.linkname
member.summary: The name of the file to link to.
member.remarks: Does not use the prefix field to produce a path name. If the path name or linkname value is too long, an error message is returned and any action on that file or directory is canceled. This field is null-terminated unless every character is non-null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.magic
member.summary: The magic number of the tar file.
member.remarks: Contains the TMAGIC value, reflecting the extended tar archive format. In this case, the uname and gname fields will contain the ASCII representation for the file owner and the file group. If a file is restored by a user with the appropriate privileges, the uid and gid fields are extracted from the password and group files (instead of the corresponding archive fields). This field is null-terminated. TMAGIC is equal to the string "USTAR", null-terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.version
member.summary: The version of the tar command used to create the file.
member.remarks: Represents the version of the tar command used to archive the file. This field is terminated with a space only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.uname
member.summary: The user name of the file owner.
member.remarks: Contains the ASCII representation of the file owner. This field is null-terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.gname
member.summary: The group name of the group owner.
member.remarks: Contains the ASCII representation of the file group. This field is null-terminated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.devmajor
member.summary: The device major number.
member.remarks: Contains the device major number. Terminated with a space and a null byte.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.devminor
member.summary: The device minor number.
member.remarks: Contains the device minor number. Terminated with a space and a null byte.

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.TarHeader.prefix
member.summary: The file name prefix.
member.remarks: If this field is non-null, the file's path name is created using the prefix/name values together. Null-terminated unless every character is non-null.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.BufferStream
member.summary: The base class for a non-seekable buffer stream.

remarks.para: A is a implementation on top of sequences of buffers. For readable streams, this sequence is an sequence. It is intended to provide an integration layer between components with different paradigms. For example, you can use a to interact with an enumerable sequence of buffers as if it were a stream.
instances have no concept of position. As such, they are not seekable, and any use of the or properties or the or methods will result in a .

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.BufferStream.CanSeek
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current stream supports seeking.
member.remarks: instances do not support seeking, so this property always returns false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.BufferStream.Length
member.summary: Gets the length in bytes of the stream. This property is not currently supported and always throws a .
member.remarks: instances do not know their length, so use of this property is not supported.

member.remarks: instances do not know their position, so use of this property is not supported.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.NtfsDirectoryJunction.Exists(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether a directory junction exists.
member.param: The directory junction to check.

remarks.para: This method checks for the existence of the junction itself, not the junction's target. To check the junction's target, use , like so:

Note that there is no difference in the NTFS file system between a symbolic link and a directory junction as far as metadata is concerned; that is, both and will return true for either a symbolic link or a directory junction.

member.summary: Delete a symbolic link.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.NtfsSymbolicLink.Exists(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether a symbolic link exists.
member.param: The symbolic link to check.
member.returns: true if the specified path exists and is a symbolic link; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: This method checks for the existence of the link itself, not the link's target. To check the link's target, use , like so:

Note that there is no difference in the NTFS file system between a symbolic link and a directory junction as far as metadata is concerned; that is, both and will return true for either a symbolic link or a directory junction.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.ShimFileSystem
member.summary: An implementation that allows the inputs and/or outputs of another to be modified before returning.
member.remarks: One of the most common modifications that needs to be performed by subclasses is manipulations of the paths on which they operate. This class provides the method, which is called by all Shim classes by default before processing. This allows for a simple way to provide a uniform transformation to be applied to all paths before processing.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.Glob
member.summary: Represents an immutable glob pattern.

remarks.para: The class represents the .NET Framework's glob engine. It can be used to quickly parse large amounts of text to find specific character patterns.

To use globs, you define the pattern that you want to identify in a text stream by using the glob patterns. Next, you can optionally instantiate a object. Finally, you call a method that determines whether the glob matches an input string.

member.summary: Moves to the next buffer in the underlying enumerable, regardless of the current position in the buffer.

member.summary: Reads data from the .

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.ReadableBufferStream.Reset
member.summary: Resets the underlying enumerator.
member.exception: The underlying enumerator does not support being reset.

remarks.para: This method calls on the underlying enumerator, so it is only supported if the underlying enumerator also supports it.

This has the effect of "rewinding" the stream back to the beginning (i.e. it is the same as calling with an offset of 0 and an origin of ). This is the only supported way to seek within a , as the method and property throw when used.

remarks.para: Allows reading of a portion of another stream as if it were a full stream.
It is impossible to open multiple instances on top of the same . Attempting to do so will result in a .

Currently, resizing a is disallowed. However, future implementation will allow passing an allowResize flag, whereafter the stream will be resizeable by using to seek outside the bounds of the stream or setting to a negative number of a number greater than .

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.WritableBufferStream.Flush
member.summary: Flushes the current buffer to the subscriber and clears it.

remarks.para: The buffer that is passed to the observer is only valid for the range of bytes between and ( + ). The value of the bytes outside this range is undefined and should not be used by the consumer.

This method will push a new to the underlying observer every time it is called, even if the buffer is empty. In the event the buffer is empty, the property will have value 0, indicating that no bytes should be read from the buffer. The only time this will happen is if is called explicitly by the consumer; will never flush an empty buffer.

member.summary: Notifies the that an observer is to receive notifications.
member.param: The object that is to receive notifications.
member.returns: A reference to an interface that allows observers to stop receiving notifications before the provider has finished sending them.
member.exception: There is already a subscription to the .
member.remarks: They value of the property for values sent to the subscriber may be reused across multiple calls to . If an observer wishes to maintain the buffers for longer than a single call to , it must copy the data into another buffer to ensure correctness.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.IO.WritableBufferStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes a sequence of bytes to the current stream and advances the current position within this stream by the number of bytes written.
member.param: An array of bytes. This method copies bytes from to the current stream.
The zero-based byte offset in at which to begin copying bytes to the current stream
The number of bytes to be written to the current stream.
member.exception: The sum of and is larger than the buffer length.

remarks.para: As data is written to the stream, it will periodically flush buffers to all subscribed observers. These flushes will occur whenever the internal buffer fills completely. The size of this internal buffer is specified in the constructor.
Buffers may also be explicitly flushed to all subscribed observers by using the method. This will clear the internal buffer, meaning the next call to will start from an empty buffer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.IEnumerableExtensions.ZipOrDefault``3(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``1},System.Func{``0,``1,``2})
member.summary: Merges two sequences by using the specified predicate function.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of the first input sequence.
The tyep of the elements of the second input sequence.
The type of the elements of the result sequence.
member.param: The first sequence to merge.
The second sequence to merge.
A function that specifies how to merge the elements from the two sequences.
member.returns: An that contains merged elements of two input sequences.

remarks.para: This method is implemented by using deferred execution. The immediate return value is an object that stores all the information that is required to perform the action. The query represented by this method is not executed until the object is enumerated either by calling its GetEnumerator method directly or by using foreach in Visual C# or For Each in Visual Basic.

The method merges each element of the first sequence with an element that has the same index in the second sequence. If the sequences do not have the same number of elements, the method merges sequences until it reaches the end of both of them, adding default values for the elements in the shorter sequence. For example, if one sequence has three elements and the other one has four, the result sequence will have four elements, one of which will contain a default value for the item in the shorter sequence.
The default value for reference and nullable types is null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress.IsBroadcast
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a broadcast address.
member.remarks: The broadcast address for IPv4 is 255.255.255.255.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress.IsIPv4MappedToIPv6
member.summary: Gets whether the IP address is an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address.
member.remarks: Dual-stack sockets always require IPv6 addresses. The ability to interact with an IPv4 address requires the use of the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format. Any IPv4 addresses must be represented in the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format which enables an IPv6 only application to communicate with an IPv4 node. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format allows the IPv4 address of an IPv4 node to be represented as an IPv6 address. The IPv4 address is encoded into the low-order 32 bits of the IPv6 address, and the high-order 96 bits hold the fixed prefix 0:0:0:0:0:FFFF. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format is specified in RFC 4291. For more information, .

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress.IsLinkLocal
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a link local address.
member.remarks: A link local address is an IPv6 address with a prefix of 0xfe80::/10.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a loopback address.
member.remarks: The loopback address for IPv4 is any address where the first octet is 127. The loopback address for IPv6 is ::1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress.IsSiteLocal
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a site local address.
member.remarks: A site local address is an IPv6 address with a prefix of 0xfec0::/10.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress.IsTeredo
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a Teredo address.
member.remarks: A teredo address is an IPv6 address with a prefix of 2001::/32. Teredo addresses can be returned through normal DNS name resolution or enumerated as an IPv6 address assigned to a local interface.

member.param: The string from which to parse the address.
member.exception: is not a valid IP address.
member.remarks: can be any valid IPv4 or IPv6 address. It may not include a port specification (:80), scope id (%12), or address prefix (/10). If is an IPv4 address, the resulting will contain an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress.ToString
member.summary: Converts an IP address to its standard notation.
member.returns: A string that contains the IP address in IPv6 colon-hexidecimal notation or IPv4 dotted-quad notation, depending on the ip address type.

remarks.para: The resulting string will have all hexadecimal characters in lower case.

If the IP address contains one or more hextets with value 0, the longest adjacent set of 0 hextets will be replaced with the :: compression indicator. If two ranges have the same number of 0 values, the leftmost one will be replaced.
If the IP address is an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address, the resulting string will be in dotted-quad notation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress.op_Explicit(Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress)~Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv4Address
member.summary: Defines an explicit conversion of an to an .
member.param: The address to convert.
member.returns: An that represents the converted .
member.remarks: This conversion is a narrowing conversion that returns the lowest 4 bytes of the IP address, regardless of its type. If the IP address is an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address, the conversion will return the equivalent address represented in IPv4. If it is a normal IPv6 address, a new IPv4 address consisting of the lowest 4 bytes of the original address is created.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddressParser
member.summary: Contains methods for parsing IPv4 and IPv6 addresses.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddressParser.ParseIPAddress(System.String)
member.summary: Parses an IP address.
member.param: The IP address to parse.
member.returns: The parsed IP address.
member.exception: is not a valid IP address.
member.remarks: This method parses an IP address in dotted-quad or colon-hexadecimal notation into an structure. The type of the underlying address depends on the format of the column. All (valid) dotted-quad addresses (X.Y.Z.Q) become IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses. All IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses (::ffff.X.Y.Z.Q) remain IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses. All other colon-hexadecimal addresses become IPv6 addresses.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddressParser.TryParseIPAddress(System.String,Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPAddress@)
member.summary: Parses an IP address.
member.param: The IP address to parse.
When this method returns, contains the parsed value if successful, or the default value for an if unsuccesful.
member.returns: true if was parsed successfully; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This method parses an IP address in dotted-quad or colon-hexadecimal notation into an structure. The type of the underlying address depends on the format of the column. All (valid) dotted-quad addresses (X.Y.Z.Q) become IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses. All IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses (::ffff.X.Y.Z.Q) remain IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses. All other colon-hexadecimal addresses become IPv6 addresses.

member.summary: Parses an IPv4 address.
member.param: The IP address to parse.
member.returns: The parsed IPv4 address.
member.exception: is not a valid IP address.
member.remarks: This method parses an IP address in dotted-quad notation into an structure. All (valid) dotted-quad addresses (X.Y.Z.Q) become IPv4 addresses. This method will throw a if represents an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv6Address.IsBroadcast
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a broadcast address.
member.remarks: IPv6 addresses do not support broadcasting; instead, see .

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv6Address.IsIPv4MappedToIPv6
member.summary: Gets whether the IP address is an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address.
member.remarks: Dual-stack sockets always require IPv6 addresses. The ability to interact with an IPv4 address requires the use of the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format. Any IPv4 addresses must be represented in the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format which enables an IPv6 only application to communicate with an IPv4 node. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format allows the IPv4 address of an IPv4 node to be represented as an IPv6 address. The IPv4 address is encoded into the low-order 32 bits of the IPv6 address, and the high-order 96 bits hold the fixed prefix 0:0:0:0:0:FFFF. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format is specified in RFC 4291. For more information, .

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv6Address.IsLinkLocal
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a link local address.
member.remarks: A link local address is an IPv6 address with a prefix of 0xfe80::/10.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv6Address.IsLoopback
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a loopback address.
member.remarks: The loopback address for IPv6 is ::1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv6Address.IsMulticast
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a multicast global address.
member.remarks: A multicast global address is an IPv6 address with a prefix of 0xff00::/8.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv6Address.IsSiteLocal
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a site local address.
member.remarks: A site local address is an IPv6 address with a prefix of 0xfec0::/10.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv6Address.IsTeredo
member.summary: Gets whether the address is a Teredo address.
member.remarks: A teredo address is an IPv6 address with a prefix of 2001::/32. Teredo addresses can be returned through normal DNS name resolution or enumerated as an IPv6 address assigned to a local interface.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Net.IPv6Address.ToString
member.summary: Converts an IP address to its standard notation.
member.returns: A string that contains the IP address in IPv6 colon-hexadecimal notation.

remarks.para: The resulting string will have all hexadecimal characters in lower case.

If the IP address contains one or more hextets with value 0, the longest adjacent set of 0 hextets will be replaced with the :: compression indicator. If two ranges have the same number of 0 values, the leftmost one will be replaced.
If the IP address is an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address, the resulting string will be an IPv4 address prefixed by ::ffff:.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.ArrayPool`1
member.summary: A pool of array segments.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the arrays.

remarks.para: The is an implementation of for values. It is intended to be used in situations where a consumer needs to create a large number of small arrays of a particular size with variable lifetimes.

The CLR's object model imposes a 16-byte (for x86) or 28-byte (for x64) overhead on each and every array instance, in addition to the actual data itself. When dealing with huge numbers of small arrays, the cost of this overhead can be exceedingly expensive. Furthermore, a large number of arrays puts pressure on the GC, as each array needs to be examined for eligiblity to be collected. The addresses both of these problems by allocating larger "array pages" from which smaller array segments can be returned. In this way, thousands of small array segments can be created from just a few physical arrays in memory.

Each instance of an creates array segments of a sepecified size. This obviates the need for solving difficult problems such as allocation, internal and external fragmentation, and compaction. However, this does make it unsuitable as a generic, arbitrarily-sized array allocation solution. In such cases, depending on the number of arrays that are expected of a given size, it may still be possible to use a separate for each distinct size; however, other solutions may also be required.
The is fully thread-safe. Multiple threads may concurrently be calling and without risk to the internal data structures of the pool.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class for creating arrays of the specified size.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ArrayPool`1.Get
member.summary: Gets an array segment from the pool.
member.returns: An array segment from the pool.

remarks.para: The stores array data in "pages". Each page corresponds to a single, physical array of type , each of which may contain multiple segments.

When getting a new segment, all existing pages are checked for free segments. If any are found, then one of them will be returned. The algorithm for which page's segment is returned is undefined. If no free segments are available, then the creates a new page and returns a segment from it.

The size of the underlying arrays created by the scale as more and more segments are requested to both minimize the overhead of requesting very few segments or very many segments of the specified size.

The method is fully thread-safe. If multiple threads are simultaneously getting and freeing segments, it is possible for a page to be created when not strictly necessary; however, there will never be a case that a segment in use can be returned by before being fully processed by .

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ArrayPool`1.FreeAsync(System.ArraySegment{`0})
member.summary: Returns an array segment to the pool asynchronously.
member.param: The array segment to return to the pool.
member.exception: points to an array that was not created by the .

remarks.para: Returning a segement to the pool will create a free slot in the associated page of the pool. Once the slot has been freed, the page will be marked as having a free slot and becomes eligible for being chosen when is called.
The method is fully thread-safe.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.ConcurrentObjectPool`1
member.summary: A generic implementation of a thread-safe object pool with a predefined size limit.
member.typeparam: The type of the objects in the pool.

remarks.para: The object pooling pattern provides a mechanism by which a limited set of objects are reused over the course of a longer-running process rather that creating and destroying them as they are needed. This pattern can be useful in a number of performance-bound situations, especially when objects are either expensive to create or destroy, or the number of objects being created puts noticeable pressure on the garbage collector, such as the rapid creation of large numbers of short lived objects within a tight loop.

This object pool implementation is focused on recycling frequently-used objects to avoid GC pressure. It has a fixed size that does not change over the course of the pool's lifetime. If an item is requested from a pool that is empty, a new item will be created using the supplied factory; if too many items are returned to the pool, any extras will be ignored (and subsequently collected). Thus, it is important to choose a reasonable capacity such that requests can be satisfied by the pool without creating new objects, but without using too much memory to store all the pooled items.
It is expected that items withdrawn from the pool are returned in a relatively short amount of time. If an object is expected to have a long lifetime, it generally shouldn't be pooled.

The does not require that calls to and be balanced; however, it will perform best if they are. It is also not a requirement that the object returned from is returned using ; any instance of the same class is sufficient.

This class is fully thread-safe and can be used safely by multiple threads without synchronization. Like many concurrent data structures, achieving this thread safety has a cost, so if you know that your pool will only ever be accessed by a single thread, using the will be slightly more performant.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ConcurrentObjectPool`1.#ctor(System.Func{`0})
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.
member.param: The function to call when creating a new item in the pool.
member.remarks: The capacity of the created by this constructor is equal to two times the number of processors. The created is empty.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ConcurrentObjectPool`1.#ctor(System.Func{`0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified capacity.
member.param: The function to call when creating a new item in the pool.
The number of items in the pool.

remarks.para: The created is empty.

The worst-case complexity of getting items from the pool and returning items to the pool is O(n), where n is the capacity of the pool. As such, it is important to keep the capacity relatively small to ensure good performance.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ConcurrentObjectPool`1.#ctor(System.Func{`0},System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified capacity that will pre-allocate the specified number of items.
member.param: The function to call when creating a new item in the pool.
The number of items in the pool.
The number of items to pre-allocate.

remarks.para: The created by this constructor will call the supplied multiple times in order to satisfy the requested initial pre-allocated size. Pre-allocation can increase initial startup time, but may decrease access time when calling .

The worst-case complexity of getting items from the pool and returning items to the pool is O(n), where n is the capacity of the pool. As such, it is important to keep the capacity relatively small to ensure good performance.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ConcurrentObjectPool`1.Get
member.summary: Gets an item from the pool.
member.returns: An item from the pool.

remarks.para: This method returns the next, non-allocated item. If the next item has not yet been created, the factory function supplied to the constructor will be invoked to create it.

If the pool has already allocated all of the items that it contains without having any returned, this method will invoke the factory function supplied to the constructor in order to create a new instance. Assuming balanced calls to and , this will result in one of the allocated items being collected by the garbage collector after being returned.

The complexity of getting an item from the pool varies depending on the number of items currently allocated and the number of threads contending for items in the pool. The worst-case complexity for getting items from the pool is O(n), where n is the capacity of the pool. The average-case complexity is amoritized to O(1). In general, the more items that have been returned from the pool, the more expensive it is to get another item. Thus, it is important to keep the capacity of the pool relatively small.

When multiple threads are contending for access to the pool, it is possible for the pool's factory function to be called even when there are free items in the pool. The frequency of this occurence is directly proportionate to the level of contention and how close to full the pool is.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.ConcurrentObjectPool`1.Free(`0)
member.summary: Returns an item to the pool.
member.param: The item to return to the pool.

remarks.para: This method returns an item to the pool. The item being returned need not have been created by calling , though in most cases it should be. The same item should not be returned to the pool more than once; doing so will result in undefined behavior.
If is null, no exception is thrown. Instead, this is treated as an unbalanced / pairing, so a future call to will result in an invocation of the factory function of the .
If the pool is currently empty, attempts to return an item to the pool will be ignored.

A consumer of an must not retain a reference to an item retrieved from the pool, nor may they continue to perform operations on the object after calling . Violating these constraints will result in undefined behavior.

The complexity of returning an item to the pool varies depending on the number of items currently allocated and the number of threads contending for items in the pool. The worst-case complexity for returning items from the pool is O(n), where n is the capacity of the pool. The average-case complexity is amoritized to O(1). In general, the more items that have been returned from the pool, the more expensive it is to return another item. Thus, it is important to keep the capacity of the pool relatively small.

When multiple threads are contending for access to the pool, it is possible for multiple items to end up occupying the same storage slot, which effectively behaves as an imbalanced / pairing. The frequency of this occurence is directly proportionate to the level of contention (but, unlike , not affected by how full the pool is).

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.RandomObjectGenerator
member.summary: Provides methods for creating and filling objects with arbitrary structure with pseudo-random values.

remarks.para: The class provides the mechanism by which to create and fill out the fields and properties of user-defined objects of relatively arbitrary structure. This class makes extensive use of reflection and the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR) for creating objects and assigning values.

The supports two methods of random generation - completely random data based on an object's type, and user-specified generation through "generators", which are simply objects that operate on dynamic objects. Unless otherwise specified, objects are filled by generating pseudo-random values for C# builtin types and by generating pseudo-random object instances for user-defined types.

When filling an object, the will only assign to a given field or property one time. A generator passed to or has the highest priority, followed by generators added via (or by adding directly to , and finally followed by pseudo-random data. If a generator only sets certain members of the object, the remaining members will be populated with pseudo-random data based on the member's type.

The is capable of automatically handling any builtin C# type as well as any class that has a default (0 parameter) constructor. For types that do not have a default constructor, the object may be created via user-supplied generator, or it will automatically be filled with null otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.RandomObjectGenerator.GeneratorsByType
member.summary: Gets a collection of generators keyed by type.

remarks.para: The dictionary contains type-specific generators, allowing specific types to be generated in certain ways. The type must be an exact match - the will not match a derived object to a generator that was added with one of it's parent classes. Similarly, it will not match any interface definitions that it happens to implement. (TODO - actually, it would be cool if it did this.)

The dictionary is a , meaning that it supports the concept of "scopes", or individual groups of keys that can be manipulated together. This allows, for example, a set of generators to be added at the same time via , some objects to be generated, and then for all the generators to be removed at the same time via . See for more details.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.
