member.summary: Adds a type-based generator to the instance's set of generators.
member.typeparam: The with which the generator is associated.
member.param: The action to be performed when filling an object of this type.

remarks.para: When matching an object to a type-based generator, the type must be an exact match - the will not match a derived object to a generator that was added with one of it's parent classes. Similarly, it will not match any interface definitions that it happens to implement. (TODO - actually, it would be cool if it did this.)

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.RandomObjectGenerator.Generate``1(System.Action{System.Object})
member.summary: Generates an object of the specified type and fills its fields and properties.
member.typeparam: The type of the object to generate.
member.param: An optional additional to apply to the object being generated.
member.returns: A newly-generated with filled fields and properties.

remarks.para: must have a default constructor in order to use this method. To fill an object without a default constructor, create the object outside of the and use instead.
If supplied, has higher priority than the instance's normal generators and default random data generation. Any members set in this generator will not be modified by the instance's normal behavior.

member.summary: Cache of retrieved objects for faster repeat access.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Schema.DsvUtilities.GetAllDsvTables(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get a containing all the DSV tables within a specified DSV.
member.param: The DSV file to read.
Whether to force reading from disk; if false, the cached table value will be used, if available.
member.returns: A containing all the DSV tables in the file.
member.exception: refers to a file that cannot be found.

remarks.para: This method returns a containing all the objects that are defined in the specified DSV.

When a DSV is read, the result is cached in order to make subsequent access faster. To force the DSV to be reread from disk, set to true. Refreshing from disk will replace any existing cache entry with the new from the DSV. Note that caching is performed based on the full name of the DSV as called from this method - if two different paths point to the same file (such as through a symbolic link, directory junction, or network share), each will have its own cache entry, and changes to one will not affect the others.

If the DSV contains one or more data tables with non-primitive types, the .NET runtime must be able to resolve these types by loading their type definition from the DLL in which they are defined. This typically means that the DLL containing the type definition must be in the executing assembly's base directory (or the app domain's base directory, if loaded as a separate app domain) or installed into the Global Assembly Cache (GAC).

Non-primitive types include most structs, collections, non-builting C# types, and any user-defined type. A column with a non-primitive type can be identified within a DSV file by looking for the msdata:DataType="fully-qualified-name, assembly-name" attribute on the column. fully-qualified-name is the fully-qualified name of the type of this column, while assembly-name is the name of the assembly in which the type is defined.

If a dsv name is provided via the parameter, when a DSV is read, the result is cached in order to make subsequent access faster. To force the DSV to be reread from disk, set to true. Refreshing from disk will replace any existing cache entry with the new from the DSV. Note that caching is performed based on the value of the parameter - if the same stream is used to load DSVs with different names, each will have its own cache entry, and changes to one will not affect the others.

If the DSV contains one or more data tables with non-primitive types, the .NET runtime must be able to resolve these types by loading their type definition from the DLL in which they are defined. This typically means that the DLL containing the type definition must be in the executing assembly's base directory (or the app domain's base directory, if loaded as a separate app domain) or installed into the Global Assembly Cache (GAC).

Non-primitive types include most structs, collections, non-builting C# types, and any user-defined type. A column with a non-primitive type can be identified within a DSV file by looking for the msdata:DataType="fully-qualified-name, assembly-name" attribute on the column. fully-qualified-name is the fully-qualified name of the type of this column, while assembly-name is the name of the assembly in which the type is defined.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.BinaryStructuredDataReader
member.summary: Reads data types from a binary stream.

remarks.para: The class provides methods that simplify reading primitive data types from a stream. For example, you can use the method to read the next byte as a value and advance the current position in the stream by one byte. The class includes read methods that support different data types.

When you create a new instance of the class, you provide the stream to read from, and optionally specify the type of encoding and whether to leave the stream open after disposing the object. If you do not specify an encoding type, UTF-8 is used.

This type implements the interface. When you have finished using the type, you should dispose of it either directly or indirectly. To dispose of the type directly, call its method in a try/catch block. To dispose of it indirectly, use a language construct such as using

member.summary: Releases all resources used by the current instance of the class.

Always call before you release your last reference to the . Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the object's Finalize method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.BinaryStructuredDataReader.Read7BitEncodedInteger
member.summary: Reads a 7-bit encoded integer.
member.returns: The integer read from the stream.
member.remarks:
7-bit encoding allows an integer to be written with fewer than 4 bytes for small, positive values.
Value Number of bytes
0-127 1 byte
128-16383 2 bytes
16384-2097151 3 bytes
2097152-268435455 4 bytes
268435456-Int32.MaxValue 5 bytes
-1-Int32.MinValue 5 bytes
Note that for negative values and for values larger than 268435455, this encoding actually requires 5 bytes per value. However, in the common case, encoding in this way helps to reduce the number of bytes used writing length prefixes for byte arrays and strings.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.BinaryStructuredDataWriter
member.summary: Writes primitive types in binary to a stream.

remarks.para: The class provides methods that simplify writing primitive data types to a stream. For example, you can use the method to write a value to the stream as a one-byte value. The class includes write methods that support different data types.

When you create a new instance of the class, you provide the stream to write to, and optionally specify the type of encoding and whether to leave the stream open after disposing the object. If you do not specify an encoding type, UTF-8 is used.

This type implements the interface. When you have finished using the type, you should dispose of it either directly or indirectly. To dispose of the type directly, call its method in a try/catch block. To dispose of it indirectly, use a language construct such as using

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.CsvStructuredDataReader
member.summary: Reads data types from a comma-separated text stream.

remarks.para: The class provides methods that simplify reading primitive data types from a stream. For example, you can use the method to read the next byte as a value and advance the current position in the stream to the next item. The class includes read methods that support different data types.
When you create a new instance of the class, you provide the stream to read from, and optionally specify the type of encoding and buffer size. If you do not specify an encoding type, UTF-8 is used.

This type implements the interface. When you have finished using the type, you should dispose of it either directly or indirectly. To dispose of the type directly, call its method in a try/catch block. To dispose of it indirectly, use a language construct such as using

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.CsvStructuredDataReader.BaseStream
member.summary: Exposes access to the underlying stream of the .
member.remarks: You can use this property to access the underlying stream. The class buffers input from the underlying stream when you call one of the Read methods. If you manipulate the position of the underlying stream after reading data into the buffer, the position of the underlying stream might not match the position of the internal buffer. To reset the internal buffer, call the method; however, this method slows performance and should be called only when absolutely necessary.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.CsvStructuredDataReader.CurrentEncoding
member.summary: Gets the current character encoding that the current object is using.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.CsvStructuredDataReader.Location
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates the current location of the in the stream.

remarks.para: The will automatically detect its location as it is being used. After every call to one of the Read methods, this property will be updated with the new location in the stream.

When the is initialized for the first time, the location will be set to until Read has been called at least once. Similarly, after calling , the location will be set to until Read has been called at least once.

You can use this property to validate that the schema of a CSV file matches the expected schema. On every line, reading each field except for the last one will set the value to . Reading the last field on the line will set the value to . If the location does not match this pattern, then the CSV file being read has a different schema than expected.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.CsvStructuredDataReader.DiscardBufferedData
member.summary: Clears the internal buffer.
member.remarks: Use the method to reset the internal buffer for the object. You need to call this method only when the position of the internal buffer and the do not match. These positions can become mismatched when you read data into the buffer and then seek a new position in the underlying stream. This method slows performance and should be used only when absolutely necessary, such as when you want to read a portion of the contents of a object more than once.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.CsvStructuredDataReader.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by the current instance of the class.

remarks.para: Call when you are finished using the . The method leaves the in an unusable state. After calling , you must release all references to the so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the was occupying.
Always call before you release your last reference to the . Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the object's Finalize method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.CsvStructuredDataReader.Microsoft#BI#Common#Serialization#IBinarySerializable#Deserialize(System.IO.BinaryReader)
member.summary: Deserializes the state of the from a stream.
member.param: The stream fropm which to read data.
member.exception: The buffer length or encoding of the serialized data does not match the buffer length and encoding of the current instance.

remarks.para: This method allows the current state of the to be restored from a serialized binary stream written with . In order for this to work properly, the following conditions must be met:

item.description: The reader must be based on the same (or an equivalent) underlying stream, and the position in the stream must be the same (or equivalent) to the position when was originally called.
The reader must have the same buffer size as the original reader.
The reader must have the same encoding as the original reader.

remarks.para: If the above conditions are met, then the restored will resume reading in exactly the same position as the original reader.

An "equivalent" stream, as mentioned above, is the original stream or another stream that contains the same data. For example, you could pass the same instance of a to the restored instance, a new where the was set to the same location as the original stream, a wrapping a , and so on.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.CsvStructuredDataWriter
member.summary: Writes primitive types to a stream in comma-separated value (CSV) format.

remarks.para: The class provides methods that simplify writing primitive data types to a stream. For example, you can use the method to write a value to the stream as a string value. The class includes write methods that support different data types.
When you create a new instance of the class, you provide the stream to read from, and optionally specify the type of encoding. If you do not specify an encoding type, UTF-8 is used.
The does not support writing fields that contain newline (\r, \n) or delimiter (,) characters. If you need to write out data that contains these characters, consider using a instead.

This type implements the interface. When you have finished using the type, you should dispose of it either directly or indirectly. To dispose of the type directly, call its method in a try/catch block. To dispose of it indirectly, use a language construct such as using

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.QuotedCsvStructuredDataReader
member.summary: Reads data types from a comma-separated text stream that is optionally quoted.

remarks.para: The class provides methods that simplify reading primitive data types from a stream. For example, you can use the method to read the next byte as a value and advance the current position in the stream to the next item. The class includes read methods that support different data types.
When you create a new instance of the class, you provide the stream to read from, and optionally specify the type of encoding and buffer size. If you do not specify an encoding type, UTF-8 is used.

This class parses data according to the RFC 4180 standard for quoting comma-separated value files. Fields may contain delimiter characters or newlines so long as the field itself is properly quoted. See http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4180 for more details.

This type implements the interface. When you have finished using the type, you should dispose of it either directly or indirectly. To dispose of the type directly, call its method in a try/catch block. To dispose of it indirectly, use a language construct such as using

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.QuotedCsvStructuredDataWriter
member.summary: Writes primitive types to a stream in comma-separated value (CSV) format.

remarks.para: The class provides methods that simplify writing primitive data types to a stream. For example, you can use the method to write a value to the stream as a string value. The class includes write methods that support different data types.
When you create a new instance of the class, you provide the stream to read from, and optionally specify the type of encoding. If you do not specify an encoding type, UTF-8 is used.

The supports writing values that contain newline (\r, \n) or delimiter (,) characters. Such fields will be quoted according to the RFC 4180 standard for CSV files. Namely, this means the field will be surrounded in quotes ("), and any embedded quotation characters will be escaped by appending an additional quote character.

This type implements the interface. When you have finished using the type, you should dispose of it either directly or indirectly. To dispose of the type directly, call its method in a try/catch block. To dispose of it indirectly, use a language construct such as using

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.GuidParser
member.summary: Provides methods for parsing values.
member.remarks: These methods are anywhere from 4.5 (for the D, B, and P formats) to 6.5 (for the N format) times faster at parsing values as compared to the builtin method. They also have no allocations. (The default .NET parser makes extensive use of when parsing, which slows everything down and allocates strings unnecessarily.)

member.name: F:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.GuidParser.NumberMaxChars
member.summary: The maximum number of characters in a string.
member.remarks:
The maximum length of a in each format is expressed in the following table:
FormatLength
N
32 characters
D
36 characters
B
38 characters
P
38 characters
X
68 characters (not yet supported)

member.summary: Provides methods for parsing hex strings into byte arrays and for formatting byte arrays into hex strings.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.HexParser.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a hex string into a byte array.
member.param: The string to parse.
member.returns: The resulting byte array.
member.exception: does not have even length, starts with "0x" and has no more characters, or contains one or more characters that are not valid hex characters.
member.remarks: This method supports parsing hex strings that optionally start with a leading "0x" or "0X" hex indicator. Both uppercase and lowercase characters are supported.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.HexParser.TryParse(System.String,System.Byte[]@)
member.summary: Parses a hex string into a byte array.
member.param: The string to parse.
When this method returns, contains the result of parsing as a byte array.
member.returns: true if the parsing was successful; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This method supports parsing hex strings that optionally start with a leading "0x" or "0X" hex indicator. Both uppercase and lowercase characters are supported.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.HexParser.Format(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Formats the supplied byte array as a string.
member.param: The byte array to format.
member.returns: The formatted string, or null if was null.

remarks.para:
The resulting string will contain the big-endian representation of the byte array (that is, the most-significant bit will be on the right and the least-significant bit will be on the left). This matches the way that byte arrays are declared. For example,
HexParser.Format(new byte[] { 0xDE, 0xAD, 0xBE, 0xEF }); // returns "DEADBEEF"
Contrast this behavior to that of , which returns a little-endian representation of the bytes being formatted.
This method does not append a leading hex indicator.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.HexParser.Format(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Formats a segment of the supplied byte array as a string.
member.param: The byte array to format.
The starting offset in at which to begin formatting.
The number of bytes to format.
member.returns: The formatted string, or null if was null.
member.exception: The sum of and is greater than the length of .

remarks.para:
The resulting string will contain the big-endian representation of the byte array (that is, the most-significant bit will be on the right and the least-significant bit will be on the left). This matches the way that byte arrays are declared. For example,
HexParser.Format(new byte[] { 0xDE, 0xAD, 0xBE, 0xEF }, 1, 2); // returns "ADBE"
Contrast this behavior to that of , which returns a little-endian representation of the bytes being formatted.
This method does not append a leading hex indicator.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.HexParser.Format(System.Byte[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Formats the supplied byte array as a string.
member.param: The byte array to format.
Whether to append a leading hex indicator.
member.returns: The formatted string.

remarks.para:
The resulting string will contain the big-endian representation of the byte array (that is, the most-significant bit will be on the right and the least-significant bit will be on the left). This matches the way that byte arrays are declared. For example,
HexParser.Format(new byte[] { 0xDE, 0xAD, 0xBE, 0xEF }, true); // returns "0xDEADBEEF"
Contrast this behavior to that of , which returns a little-endian representation of the bytes being formatted.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.HexParser.Format(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Formats the supplied byte array as a string.
member.param: The byte array to format.
The starting offset in at which to begin formatting.
The number of bytes to format.
Whether to append a leading hex indicator.
member.returns: The formatted string.
member.exception: The sum of and is greater than the length of .

remarks.para:
The resulting string will contain the big-endian representation of the byte array (that is, the most-significant bit will be on the right and the least-significant bit will be on the left). This matches the way that byte arrays are declared. For example,
HexParser.Format(new byte[] { 0xDE, 0xAD, 0xBE, 0xEF }, 1, 2, true); // returns "0xADBE"
Contrast this behavior to that of , which returns a little-endian representation of the bytes being formatted.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.HexParser.Format(System.Byte*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Formats the supplied bytes as a string.
member.param: A pointer to the byte at which to start formatting.
The number of bytes to format.
member.returns: The formatted string, or null if was null.

remarks.para:
The resulting string will contain the little-endian representation of the bytes (that is, the least-significant bit will be on the right and the most-significant bit will be on the left). This matches the way that integral values formatted with the "X" format specifier are returned. For example,
long value = 1234567890; HexParser.Format((byte*)&value, 8); // returns "00000000499602D2" value.ToString("X16"); // returns "00000000499602D2"
Contrast this behavior to that of , which returns a little-endian representation of the bytes being formatted.
This method does not append a leading hex indicator.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.HexParser.Format(System.Byte*,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Formats the supplied bytes as a string.
member.param: A pointer to the byte at which to start formatting.
The number of bytes to format.
Whether to append a leading hex indicator.
member.returns: The formatted string, or null if was null.

remarks.para:
The resulting string will contain the little-endian representation of the bytes (that is, the least-significant bit will be on the right and the most-significant bit will be on the left). This matches the way that integral values formatted with the "X" format specifier are returned. For example,
long value = 1234567890; HexParser.Format((byte*)&value, 8, false); // returns "00000000499602D2" value.ToString("X16"); // returns "00000000499602D2"
Contrast this behavior to that of , which returns a little-endian representation of the bytes being formatted.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Serialization.NumberParser.UInt32ToDecimalChars(System.Char*,System.UInt32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Fills a char buffer with the decimal characters of the specified value.
member.param: A pointer to the end of buffer at which to start filling characters.
The value.
The minimum number of digits to return from .
member.returns: The position in the character buffer of the beginning of the number's characters.

remarks.para: The buffer pointed to by is filled from high-order values to low-order values - that is, the rightmost character will have the highest address and the leftmost character will have the lowest address. The characters of the number will end in a null character to terminate the string.
It is the responsibility of the caller to supply a buffer large enough to contain the entire number plus the null terminator.

remarks.para: The buffer pointed to by is filled from high-order values to low-order values - that is, the rightmost character will have the highest address and the leftmost character will have the lowest address. The characters of the number will end in a null character to terminate the string.
It is the responsibility of the caller to supply a buffer large enough to contain the entire number plus the null terminator.
If is not one of 'x' or 'X', the behavior of this method is undefined.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Text.Base64Encoding
member.summary: Represents a base-64 character encoding of a byte array.

remarks.para: Unlike most standard implementations, the is a binary-to-text encoding (as opposed to a text-to-binary encoding). That is, from the perspective of a , encoding is the process of transforming a sequence of bytes into a set of Unicode characters., and decoding is the process of transforming a set of Unicode characters into a sequence of bytes.

Base-64 is an encoding that represents each sequence of 3 bytes with 4 Unicode characters by translating it into a radix-64 representation. It uses the characters 'A'-'Z', 'a'-'z', '0'-'9', and two additional characters to encode the remaining two values. Base-64 encoding is designed to contain only ASCII characters so that it is unlikely to be modified in transit through systems that are not "8-bit clean".

You can instantiate a object in a number of ways, depending on the characters you want to use for indexes 62 and 63, the character you want to use for padding, and whether or not you want to pad at all. The following table lists the constructors and properties that return a object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Text.Base64Encoding.Base64Default
member.summary: Gets an encoding for default base-64 encoding.
member.remarks: The default base-64 encoding uses characters '+' and '/' for indexes 62 and 63, respectively, and has mandatory padding using the '=' character.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Text.Base64Encoding.Base64Url
member.summary: Gets an encoding for base-64 URL encoding.
member.remarks: The base-64 URL encoding uses characters '-' and '_' for indexes 62 and 63, respectively, and has optional padding using the '=' character.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Text.Base64Encoding.Base64Xml
member.summary: Gets an encoding for base-64 XML encoding.
member.remarks: The base-64 XML encoding uses characters '_' and ':' for indexes 62 and 63, respectively, and does not use padding.

member.name: P:Microsoft.BI.Common.Text.Base64Encoding.Base64Regex
member.summary: Gets an encoding for base-64 regular expression encoding.
member.remarks: The base-64 regular expression encoding uses characters '!' and '-' for indexes 62 and 63, respectively, and does not use padding.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.RFC4180DelimitedTextParser.ReadLine
member.summary: Returns the current line as a string and advances the cursor to the next line.
member.returns: The current line from the file or stream.
member.remarks: This may not be the exact string in the file - each item is still processed according to RFC4180, so there may be small modifications (like removing of unquoted leading and trailing whilespace, for example).

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.Threading.ManualResetLock
member.summary: Locking mechanism where threads can wait for a lock to become available but not necessarily take the lock.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Threading.ManualResetLock.#ctor
member.summary: Create a with an initial state where threads will not block on by default.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Threading.ManualResetLock.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a with an initial state.
member.param: true if the signal is set so threads block on ; false otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Threading.ManualResetLock.TryEnter
member.summary: Attempt to secure the lock.
member.returns: true if successfully obtained the lock; false otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Threading.ManualResetLock.Exit
member.summary: Release the lock and let threads resume that are waiting.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Threading.ManualResetLock.Wait
member.summary: Wait until the lock has been yielded.
member.remarks: Threads should continuously try to as it is possible that the thread is interupted between yielding the lock and reseting the event.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Threading.ManualResetLock.Wait(System.Int32)
member.summary: Wait until the lock has been yielded or the timeout has been exceeded.
member.remarks: Threads should continuously try to as it is possible that the thread is interupted between yielding the lock and reseting the event.
member.param: The timeout in milliseconds. -1 indicates a timeout of infinity.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Threading.ManualResetLock.Wait(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Wait until the lock has been yielded or the timeout has been exceeded.
member.remarks: Threads should continuously try to as it is possible that the thread is interupted between yielding the lock and reseting the event.
member.param: The timeout as a . A representing -1 milliseconds indicates a timeout of infinity.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.TimeSpanExtensions.Multiply(System.TimeSpan,System.Int64)
member.summary: Returns a new object whose value is multiplied by the specified number.
member.param: The value to multiply.
The value by which to multiply the .
member.returns: A new that represents the value of this instance multiplied by .
member.exception: The resulting is less than or greater than .

remarks.para: The return value must be between and ; otherwise, an exception is thrown.
The return value is a new ; the original is not modified.

Like standard multiplication, multiplying a positive value by a positive number will result in a positive , multiplying a negative value by a positive number or a positive value by a negative number will result in a negative , and multiplying a negative value by a positive number will result in a positive .

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.TimeSpanExtensions.Divide(System.TimeSpan,System.Int64)
member.summary: Returns a new object whose value is divided by the specified number.
member.param: The value to divide.
The value by which to divide the .
member.returns: A new that represents the value of this instance divided by .
member.exception: The resulting is less than or greater than .

remarks.para: The return value must be between and ; otherwise, an exception is thrown.
The return value is a new ; the original is not modified.

Like standard division, dividing a positive value by a positive number will result in a positive , dividing a negative value by a positive number or a positive value by a negative number will result in a negative , and dividing a negative value by a positive number will result in a positive .
Division performed by this method is integral, meaning all fractional remainders are rounded down.

member.name: M:Microsoft.BI.Common.Triple`3.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a value that indicates whether the current object is equal to a specified object.
member.param: The object to compare with this instance.
member.returns: true if the current instance is equal to the specified object; otherwise, false.

remarks.para:
The parameter is considered to be equal to the current instance under the following conditions:
It is a object.
Its three components are of the same type as the current instance.
Its three components are equal to those of the current instance. Equality is determined by the default object equality comparer for each component.

member.name: T:Microsoft.BI.Common.XmlSerializationFactory
member.summary: A factory for creating objects.

remarks.para: Using the class causes an assembly to be compiled and loaded into the current app domain. Two of the constructors, and , utilize an internal cache to avoid leaking memory for each serializer created; however, none of the others do.
All instances created through this factory utilize a shared cache. If a is requested with the same arguments twice, a cached version will be returned rather than generating a new one.
This factory has the same API as the constructors, with the exception of two of the constructors. One is deprecated and will not be added; the other may be added if we find a need for it later.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.AdvApi32NativeMethods.LUID.HighPart

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.AdvApi32NativeMethods.LUID_AND_ATTRIBUTES.Attributes
member.summary: Specifies attributes of the LUID. This value contains up to 32 one-bit flags. Its meaning is dependent on the definition and use of the LUID.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.AdvApi32NativeMethods.TOKEN_PRIVILEGES.Privileges
member.summary: Specifies an array of structures. Each structure contains the LUID and attributes of a privilege. To get the name of the privilege associated with a LUID, call the LookupPrivilegeName function, passing the address of the LUID as the value of the lpLuid parameter.

member.summary: Enables or disables privileges in the specified access token. Enabling or disabling privileges in an access token requires TOKEN_ADJUST_PRIVILEGES access.
member.param: A handle to the access token that contains the privileges to be modified.
Specifies whether the function disables all of the token's privileges.
A pointer to a structure that specifies an array of privileges and their attributes.
Specifies the size, in bytes, of the buffer pointed to by the parameter.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Enables or disables privileges in the specified access token. Enabling or disabling privileges in an access token requires TOKEN_ADJUST_PRIVILEGES access.
member.param: A handle to the access token that contains the privileges to be modified.

A pointer to a structure that specifies an array of privileges and their attributes.
Specifies the size, in bytes, of the buffer pointed to by the parameter.
A pointer to a buffer that the function fills with a structure that contains the previous state of any privileges that the function modifies.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.FUSION_INSTALL_REFERENCE
member.summary: Represents a reference that is made when an application has installed an assembly in the GAC.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.FUSION_INSTALL_REFERENCE.cbSize
member.summary: The size of the structure, in bytes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.FUSION_INSTALL_REFERENCE.dwFlags
member.summary: Reserved, must be zero.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.FUSION_INSTALL_REFERENCE.guidScheme
member.summary: The entity that adds the reference.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.FUSION_INSTALL_REFERENCE.szIdentifier
member.summary: A unique string that identifies the application that installed the assembly.

item.description: The assembly is referenced by an application that has been installed by using Windows Installer. The szIdentifier field is set to MSI, and szNonCannonicalData is set to Windows Installer. This scheme must only be used by Windows Installer itself.
The assembly is referenced by an application that appears in Add/Remove Programs. The szIdentifier field is the token that is used to register the application with Add/Remove programs.
The assembly is referenced by an application that is represented by a file in the file system. The szIdentifier field is the path to this file.

The assembly is referenced by an application that is only represented by an opaque string. The szIdentifier is this opaque string. The GAC does not perform existence checking for opaque references when you remove this.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.FUSION_INSTALL_REFERENCE.szNonCannonicalData
member.summary: A string that is only understood by the entity that adds the reference. The GAC only stores this string.

GUID

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.IAssemblyCache
member.summary: The top-level interface that provides access to the GAC.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.IAssemblyCache.UninstallAssembly(System.UInt32,System.String,Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.FUSION_INSTALL_REFERENCE[],System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Removes a reference to an assembly from the GAC. If other applications hold no other references to the assembly, the files that make up the assembly are removed from the GAC.
member.param: No flags defined. Must be zero.
The name of the assembly. A zero-ended Unicode string.
A pointer to a structure. Although this is not recommended, this parameter can be null. The assembly is installed without an application reference, or all existing application references are gone.
Pointer to an integer that indicates the action that is performed by the function.
member.returns:
The return values are defined as follows:
Return value Description
S_OK The assembly has been uninstalled.
S_FALSE The operation succeeded, but the assembly was not removed from the GAC. The reason is described in .
member.remarks:
NOTE: If is not null, it will contain one of the following values:
Return value Description
IASSEMBLYCACHE_UNINSTALL_DISPOSITION_UNINSTALLED The assembly files have been removed from the GAC.
IASSEMBLYCACHE_UNINSTALL_DISPOSITION_STILL_IN_USE An application is using the assembly. This value is returned on Microsoft Windows 95 and Microsoft Windows 98.
IASSEMBLYCACHE_UNINSTALL_DISPOSITION_ALREADY_UNINSTALLED The assembly does not exist in the GAC.
IASSEMBLYCACHE_UNINSTALL_DISPOSITION_DELETE_PENDING Not used.
IASSEMBLYCACHE_UNINSTALL_DISPOSITION_HAS_INSTALL_REFERENCES The assembly has not been removed from the GAC because another application reference exists.
IASSEMBLYCACHE_UNINSTALL_DISPOSITION_REFERENCE_NOT_FOUND The reference that is specified in pRefData is not found in the GAC.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.IAssemblyCache.QueryAssemblyInfo(System.UInt32,System.String,Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.ASSEMBLY_INFO@)
member.summary: Retrieves information about an assembly from the GAC.
member.param:
One of or :
Flag Description
QUERYASMINFO_FLAG_VALIDATE Performs validation of the files in the GAC against the assembly manifest, including hash verification and strong name signature verification.
QUERYASMINFO_FLAG_GETSIZE Returns the size of all files in the assembly (disk footprint). If this is not specified, the field is not modified.
Name of the assembly that is queried.
Pointer to the returned structure.
member.returns: Whether the operation succeeded or not.

member.summary: Undocumented.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.IAssemblyCache.CreateAssemblyScavenger(System.Object@)
member.summary: Undocumented.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.IAssemblyCache.InstallAssembly(System.UInt32,System.String,Microsoft.Win32.FusionNativeMethods.FUSION_INSTALL_REFERENCE[])
member.summary: Adds a new assembly to the GAC. The assembly must be persisted in the file system and is copied to the GAC.
member.param:
At most, one of the bits of the values can be specified:
Flag Description
IASSEMBLY_INSTALL_FLAG_REFRESH If the assembly is already installed in the GAC and the file version numbers of the assembly being installed are the same or later, the files are replaced.
IASSEMBLY_INSTALL_FLAG_FORCE_REFRESH The files of an existing assembly are overwritten regardless of their version number.
A string pointing to the dynamic-linked library (DLL) that contains the assembly manifest. Other assembly files must reside in the same directory as the DLL that contains the assembly manifest.

A pointer to a that indicates the application on whose behalf the assembly is being installed. Although this is not recommended, this parameter can be null, but this leaves the assembly without any application reference.
member.returns: Whether the operation succeeded or not.

member.summary: Returns a string representation of the assembly name.
member.param: A pointer to a buffer that is to contain the display name. The display name is returned in Unicode.
The size of the buffer in characters (on input). The length of the returned display name (on return).

One or more of the bits defined in the enumeration:
Flag Description
VERSION Includes the version number as part of the display name.
CULTURE Includes the culture.
PUBLIC_KEY_TOKEN Includes the public key token.
PUBLIC_KEY Includes the public key.
CUSTOM Includes the custom part of the assembly name.
PROCESSORARCHITECTURE Includes the processor architecture.
LANGUAGEID Includes the language ID.
member.returns: Whether the operation succeeded or not.
member.remarks: See library documentation at http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/cpguide/html/cpcondefaultmarshalingforstrings.asp for details.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods
member.summary: Contains native methods in kernel32.dll.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType
member.summary: Contains values for the flAllocationType parameter to .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.COMMIT
member.summary: Allocates memory charges (from the overall size of memory and the paging files on disk) for the specified reserved memory pages.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.RESERVE
member.summary: Reserves a range of the process's virtual address space without allocating any actual physical storage in memory or in the paging file on disk.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.FREE
member.summary: Reserved pages where a range of the process's virtual address space is reserved without any physical storage being allocated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.RESET
member.summary: Indicates that data in the memory range specified by lpAddress and dwSize is no longer of interest.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.TOP_DOWN
member.summary: Allocates memory at the highest possible address.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.WRITE_WATCH
member.summary: Causes the system to track pages that are written to in the allocated region.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.PHYSICAL
member.summary: Reserves an address range that can be used to map Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) pages.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.RESET_UNDO
member.summary: Indicates that the data in the specified memory range specified by lpAddress and dwSize is of interest to the caller and attempts to reverse the effects of .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType.LARGE_PAGES
member.summary: Allocates memory using large page support.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.CreationDisposition
member.summary: Contains values for the dwCreationDisposition parameter to .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.CreationDisposition.CREATE_ALWAYS
member.summary: Creates a new file, always.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.CreationDisposition.CREATE_NEW
member.summary: Creates a new file, only if it does not already exist.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.CreationDisposition.OPEN_ALWAYS
member.summary: Opens a file, always.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.CreationDisposition.OPEN_EXISTING
member.summary: Opens a file or device, only if it exists.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.CreationDisposition.TRUNCATE_EXISTING
member.summary: Opens a file and truncates it so that its size is zero bytes, only if it exists.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess
member.summary: Contains values for the dwDesiredAccess parameter to .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.DELETE
member.summary: The right to delete the object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.READ_CONTROL
member.summary: The right to read the information in the object's security descriptor, not including the information in the system access control list (SACL).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.WRITE_DAC
member.summary: The right to modify the discretionary access control list (DACL) in the object's security descriptor.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.WRITE_OWNER
member.summary: The right to change the owner in the object's security descriptor.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.SYNCHRONIZE
member.summary: The right to use the object for synchronization. This enables a thread to wait until the object is in the signaled state. Some object types do not support this access right.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.STANDARD_RIGHTS_REQUIRED
member.summary: Combines , , , and access.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.STANDARD_RIGHTS_READ
member.summary: Includes , which is the right to read the information in the file or directory object's security descriptor. This does not include the information in the SACL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.STANDARD_RIGHTS_WRITE
member.summary: Same as

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.STANDARD_RIGHTS_EXECUTE
member.summary: Currently defined to equal .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.STANDARD_RIGHTS_ALL
member.summary: Combines , , , , and access.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.FILE_READ_DATA
member.summary: For a file object, the right to read the corresponding file data. For a directory object, the right to read the corresponding directory data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.FILE_LIST_DIRECTORY
member.summary: For a directory, the right to list the contents of the directory.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.FILE_WRITE_DATA
member.summary: For a file object, the right to write data to the file. For a directory object, the right to create a file in the directory ().

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.FILE_ADD_FILE
member.summary: For a directory, the right to create a file in the directory.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAccess.FILE_APPEND_DATA
member.summary: For a file object, the right to append data to the file. (For local files, write operations will not overwrite existing data if this flag is specified without .) For a directory object, the right to create a subdirectory ().

member.summary: The file is part of or used exclusively by an operating system.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TEMPORARY
member.summary: The file is being used for temporary storage.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_BACKUP_SEMANTICS
member.summary: The file is being opened or created for a backup or restore operation. The system ensures that the calling process overrides file security checks when the process has SE_BACKUP_NAME and SE_RESTORE_NAME privileges.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_DELETE_ON_CLOSE
member.summary: The file is to be deleted immediately after all of its handles are closed, which includes the specified handle and any other open or duplicated handles.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with no system caching for data reads and writes. This flag does not affect hard disk caching or memory mapped files.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OPEN_NO_RECALL
member.summary: The file data is requested, but it should continue to be located in remote storage. It should not be transported back to local storage.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OPEN_REPARSE_POINT
member.summary: Normal reparse point processing will not occur; will attempt to open the reparse point. When a file is opened, a file handle is returned, whether or not the filter that controls the reparse point is operational. This flag cannot be used with the CREATE_ALWAYS flag. If the file is not a reparse point, then this flag is ignored.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED
member.summary: The file or device is being opened or created for asynchronous I/O. When subsequent I/O operations are completed on this handle, the event specified in the OVERLAPPED structure will be set to the signaled state.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_POSIX_SEMANTICS
member.summary: Access will occur according to POSIX rules. This includes allowing multiple files with names, differing only in case, for file systems that support that naming. Use care when using this option, because files created with this flag may not be accessible by applications that are written for MS-DOS or 16-bit Windows.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_RANDOM_ACCESS
member.summary: Access is intended to be random. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_SESSION_AWARE
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with session awareness. If this flag is not specified, then per-session devices (such as a redirected USB device) cannot be opened by processes running in session 0. This flag has no effect for callers not in session 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_SEQUENTIAL_SCAN
member.summary: Access is intended to be sequential from beginning to end. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FileAttributes.FILE_FLAG_WRITE_THROUGH
member.summary: Write operations will not go through any intermediate cache, they will go directly to disk.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags
member.summary: Contains values for the flOptions parameter in

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags.HEAP_NO_SERIALIZATION
member.summary: Serialized access is not used when the heap functions access this heap.

remarks.para: This option applies to all subsequent heap function calls. Alternatively, you can specify this option on individual heap function calls.
The low-fragmentation heap (LFH) cannot be enabled for a heap created with this option.
A heap created with this option cannot be locked. Attempting to do so will result in undefined behavior.

If is not specified, the heap serializes access within the calling process. Serialization ensures mutual exclusion when two or more threads attempt simultaneously to allocate or free blocks from the same heap. There is a small performance cost to serialization, but it must be used whenever multiple threads allocate and free memory from the same heap. The and functions can be used to block and permit access to a serialized heap.

Setting eliminates mutual exclusion on the heap. Without serialization, two or more threads that use the same heap handle might attempt to allocate or free memory simultaneously, which may cause corruption in the heap. Therefore, can safely be used only in the following situations:
The process has only one thread.
The process has multiple threads, but only one thread calls the heap functions for a specific heap.
The process has multiple threads, and the application provides its own mechanism for mutual exclusion to a specific heap.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags.HEAP_GENERATE_EXCEPTIONS
member.summary: The system raises an exception to indicate failure (for example, an out-of-memory condition) for calls to and instead of returning null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags.HEAP_REALLOC_IN_PLACE_ONLY
member.summary: There can be no movement when reallocating a memory block. If this value is not specified, the function may move the block to a new location. If this value is specified and the block cannot be resized without moving, the function fails, leaving the original memory block unchanged.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags.HEAP_ZERO_MEMORY
member.summary: If the reallocation request is for a larger size, the additional region of memory beyond the original size be initialized to zero. The contents of the memory block up to its original size are unaffected.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags.HEAP_CREATE_ENABLE_EXECUTE
member.summary: All memory blocks that are allocated from this heap allow code execution, if the hardware enforces data execution prevention.
member.remarks: Use this flag heap in applications that run code from the heap. If is not specified and an application attempts to run code from a protected page, an will be thrown.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.CheckRemoteDebuggerPresent(System.Runtime.InteropServices.SafeHandle,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified process is being debugged.
member.param: A handle to the process.
A pointer to a variable that the function sets to true if the specified process is being debugged, or false otherwise.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: The "remote" in does not imply that the debugger necessarily resides on a different computer; instead, it indicates that the debugger resides in a separate and parallel process. Use the IsDebuggerPresent function to detect whether the calling process is running under the debugger.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.GetProcessHeap
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the default heap of the calling process. This handle can then be used in subsequent calls to the heap functions.
member.returns: A handle to the calling process' heap, or null if the function fails.

remarks.para: The function obtains a handle to the default heap for the calling process. A process can use this handle to allocate memory from the process heap without having to first create a private heap using the function.
To enable the low-fragmentation heap for the default heap of the process, call the HeapSetInformation function with the handle returned by .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapAlloc(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Allocates a block of memory from a heap. The allocated memory is not movable.
member.param: A handle to the heap from which the memory will be allocated.
The heap allocation options. Specifying any of these values will override the corresponding value specified when the heap was created with
The number of bytes to be allocated.
member.returns: A pointer to the allocated memory block, or null if the function fails.

remarks.para: If the function succeeds, it allocates at least the amount of memory requested.
If the heap specified by the parameter is a "non-growable" heap, must be less than 0x7FFF8. You create a non-growable heap by calling the function with a nonzero value.
To allocate memory from the process's default heap, use with the handle returned by the function.
To free a block of memory allocated by , use the function.

Memory allocated by is not movable. The address returned by is valid until the memory block is freed or reallocated; the memory block does not need to be locked. Because the system cannot compact a private heap, it can become fragmented. Applications that allocate large amounts of memory in various allocation sizes can use the low-fragmentation heap to reduce heap fragmentation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapCreate(Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a private heap object that can be used by the calling process. The function reserves space in the virtual address space of the process and allocates physical storage for a specified initial portion of this block.
member.param: The heap allocation options.
The initial size of the heap, in bytes.
The maximum size of the heap, in bytes.
member.returns: A handle to the newly created heap, or null if the function fails.

remarks.para: The function creates a private heap object from which the calling process can allocate memory blocks by using the function. The initial size determines the number of committed pages that are allocated initially for the heap. The maximum size determines the total number of reserved pages. These pages create a block in the process's virtual address space into which the heap can grow. If requests by exceed the current size of committed pages, additional pages are automatically committed from this reserved space, if the physical storage is available.
By default, the newly created private heap is a standard heap. To enable the low-fragmentation heap, call the HeapSetInformation function with a handle to the private heap.

The memory of a private heap object is accessible only to the process that created it. If a dynamic-link library (DLL) creates a private heap, the heap is created in the address space of the process that calls the DLL, and it is accessible only to that process.

The system uses memory from the private heap to store heap support structures, so not all of the specified heap size is available to the process. For example, if the function requests 64 kilobytes from a heap with a maximum size of 64K, the request may fail because of system overhead.

To obtain a handle to the default heap for a process, use the function. To obtain handles to the default heap and private heaps that are active for the calling process, use the GetProcessHeaps function.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapDestroy(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Destroys the specified heap object. It decommits and releases all the pages of a private heap object, and it invalidates the handle to the heap.
member.param: A handle to the heap to be destroyed.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: Processes can call without first calling the function to free memory allocated from the heap.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFree(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags,System.Void*)
member.summary: Frees a memory block allocated from a heap by the or function.
member.param: A handle to the heap whose memory block is to be freed.
The heap free options. Specifying any of these values will override the corresponding value specified when the heap was created with
A pointer to the memory block to be freed.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: You should not refer in any way to memory that has been freed by . After that memory is freed, any information that may have been in it is gone forever. If you require information, do not free memory containing the information. Function calls that return information about memory (such as ) may not be used with freed memory, as they may return bogus data. Calling twice with the same pointer can cause heap corruption, resulting in subsequent calls to returning the same pointer twice.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapLock(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Attempts to acquire the critical section object, or lock, that is associated with a specified heap.
member.param: A handle to the heap to be locked.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: If the function succeeds, the calling thread owns the heap lock. Only the calling thread will be able to allocate or release memory from the heap. The execution of any other thread of the calling process will be blocked if that thread attempts to allocate or release memory from the heap. Such threads will remain blocked until the thread that owns the heap lock calls the function.
The function is primarily useful for preventing the allocation and release of heap memory by other threads while the calling thread uses the HeapWalk function.
If the function is called on a heap created with the flag, the result is undefined.
Each successful call to must be matched by a corresponding call to . Failure to call will block the execution of any other threads of the calling process that attempt to access the heap.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapReAlloc(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags,System.Void*,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Reallocates a block of memory from a heap. This function enables you to resize a memory block and change other memory block properties. The allocated memory is not movable.
member.param: A handle to the heap from which the memory will be reallocated.
The heap reallocation options. Specifying any of these values will override the corresponding value specified when the heap was created with
A pointer to the block of memory that the function reallocates.
The new size of the memory block, in bytes.
member.returns: A pointer to the allocated memory block, or null if the function fails.

remarks.para: If the function succeeds, it allocates at least the amount of memory requested.
If the function fails, the original memory is not freed, and the original handle and pointer are still valid.

is guaranteed to preserve the content of the memory being reallocated, even if the new memory is allocated at a different location. The process of preserving the memory content involves a memory copy operation that is potentially very time-consuming.
If the heap specified by the parameter is a "non-growable" heap, must be less than 0x7FFF8. You create a non-growable heap by calling the function with a nonzero value.
To free a block of memory allocated by , use the function.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapSize(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.HeapFlags,System.Void*)
member.summary: Retrieves the size of a memory block allocated from a heap by the or function.
member.param: A handle to the heap in which the memory block resides.
The heap size options. Specifying any of these values will override the corresponding value specified when the heap was created with
A pointer to the memory block whos size the function will obtain.
member.returns: The requested size of the allocated memory block, in bytes, or -1 if the function fails.

remarks.para: If the parameter refers to a heap allocation that is not in the heap specified by the parameter, the behavior of the function is undefined.

member.summary: Releases ownership of the critical section object, or lock, that is associated with a specified heap.
member.param: A handle to the heap to be unlocked.

If the function is called on a heap created with the flag, the result is undefined.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.LocalAlloc(Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.LocalAllocFlags,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allocates the specified number of bytes from the heap.
member.param: The memory allocation attributes.
The number of bytes to allocate.
member.returns: A handle to the newly-allocated memory, or null if allocation failed.

remarks.para: The movable-memory flags , , and add unnecessary overhead and require locking to be used safely. They should be avoided unless documentation specifically states that they should be used.

If the heap does not contain sufficient free space to satisfy the request, returns null. Because null is used to indicate an error, virtual address zero is never allocated. It is, therefore, easy to detect the use of a null pointer.

If the function succeeds, it allocates at least the amount requested. If the amount allocated is greater than the amount requested, the process can use the entire amount. To determine the actual number of bytes allocated, use the function.
To free the memory, use the function. It is not safe to free memory allocated with using GlobalFree.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.LocalFree(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Frees the specified local memory object and invalidates its handle.
member.param: A handle to the local memory object.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is null. If it fails, it is equal to the .

remarks.para: If the process tries to examine or modify the memory after it has been freed, heap corruption may occur or an access violation exception (EXCEPTION_ACCESS_VIOLATION) may be generated.
If the parameter is null, ignores the parameter and returns null.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.LocalSize(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Retrieves the current size of the specified local memory object, in bytes.
member.param: A handle to the local memory object.
member.returns: The size of the specified local memory object, in bytes.

remarks.para: The size of a memory block may be larger than the size requested when the memory was allocated.
To verify that the specified object's memory block has not been discarded, call the LocalFlags function before calling .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.VirtualAlloc(System.IntPtr,System.UIntPtr,Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.AllocationType,Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.MemoryProtection)
member.summary: Reserves or commits a region of pages in the virtual address space of the calling process. Memory allocated by this function is automatically initialized to zero, unless is specified.
member.param: The starting address of the region to allocate.
The size of the region, in bytes.
The type of memory allocation.
The memory protection for the region of pages to be allocated.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the base address of the allocated region of pages. If the function fails, the return value is null.

remarks.para:
Each page has an associated page state. The function can perform the following operations:
Commit a region of reserved pages
Reserve a region of free pages
Simultaneously reserve and commit a region of free pages
cannot reserve a reserved page. It can commit a page that is already committed. This means you can commit a range of pages, regardless of whether they have already been committed, and the function will not fail.

You can use to reserve a block of pages and then make additional calls to to commit individual pages from the reserved block. This enables a process to reserve a range of its virtual address space without consuming physical storage until it is needed.

If the parameter is not null, the function uses the and parameters to compute the region of pages to be allocated. The current state of the entire range of pages must be compatible with the type of allocation specified by the parameter. Otherwise, the function fails and none of the pages are allocated. This compatibility requirement does not preclude committing an already committed page, as mentioned previously.
To execute dynamically generated code, use to allocate memory and the VirtualProtect function to grant access.

The function can be used to reserve an Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) region of memory within the virtual address space of a specified process. This region of memory can then be used to map physical pages into and out of virtual memory as required by the application. The and values must be set in the parameter. The value must not be set. The page protection must be set to .
The function can decommit a committed page, releasing the page's storage, or it can simultaneously decommit and release a committed page. It can also release a reserved page, making it a free page.

When creating a region that will be executable, the calling program bears responsibility for ensuring cache coherency via an appropriate call to FlushInstructionCache once the code has been set in place. Otherwise, attempts to execute code out of the newly executable region may produce unpredictable results.

When reserving memory, the specified address is rounded down to the nearest multiple of the allocation granularity. If the memory is already reserved and is being committed, the address is rounded down to the next page boundary. To determine the size of a page and the allocation granularity on the host computer, use the GetSystemInfo function. If this parameter is null, the system determines where to allocate the region.

If the parameter is null, the value is rounded up to the next page boundary. Otherwise, the allocated pages include all pages containing one or more bytes in the range from to + . This means that a 2-byte range straddling a page boundary causes both pages to be included in the allocated region.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.VirtualQuery(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Retrieves information about a range of pages in the virtual address space of the calling process.
member.param: A pointer to the base address of the region of pages to be queried. This value is rounded down to the next page boundary.
A pointer to a structure in which information about the specified page range is returned.
The size of the buffer pointed to by the parameter, in bytes.
member.returns: The actual number of bytes returned in the information buffer.

remarks.para:
provides information about a region of consecutive pages beginning at a specified address that share the following attributes:
The state of all pages is the same (MEM_COMMIT, MEM_RESERVE, MEM_FREE, MEM_PRIVATE, MEM_MAPPED, or MEM_IMAGE).
If the initial page is not free, all pages in the region are part of the same initial allocation of pages created by a single call to , MapViewOfFile MapViewOfFile, or one of the extended versions of these functions.
The access granted to all pages is the same (one of the values.

The function determines the attributes of the first page in the region and then scans subsequent pages until it scans the entire range of pages or until it encounters a page with a nonmatching set of attributes. The function returns the attributes and the size of the region of pages with matching attributes, in bytes. For example, if there is a 40 megabyte (MB) region of free memory, and is called on a page that is 10 MB into the region, the function will obtain a state of and a size of 30 MB.

If a shared copy-on-write page is modified, it becomes private to the process that modified the page. However, the function will continue to report such pages as MEM_MAPPED (for data views) or MEM_IMAGE (for executable image views) rather than MEM_PRIVATE. To detect whether copy-on-write has occurred for a specific page, either access the page or lock it using the VirtualLock function to make sure the page is resident in memory, then use the QueryWorkingSetEx function to check the Shared bit in the extended working set information for the page. If the Shared bit is clear, the page is private.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.VirtualFree(System.IntPtr,System.UIntPtr,Microsoft.Win32.Kernel32NativeMethods.FreeType)
member.summary: Releases, decommits, or releases and decommits a region of pages within the virtual address space of the calling process.
member.param: A pointer to the base address of the region of pages to be freed.
The size of the region of memory to be freed, in bytes.
The type of free operation.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is 0 (zero).

remarks.para: Each page of memory in a process virtual address space has a Page State. The function can decommit a range of pages that are in different states, some committed and some uncommitted. This means that you can decommit a range of pages without first determining the current commitment state of each page. Decommitting a page releases its physical storage, either in memory or in the paging file on disk.

If a page is decommitted but not released, its state changes to reserved. Subsequently, you can call to commit it, or to release it. Attempts to read from or write to a reserved page results in an access violation exception.

The function can release a range of pages that are in different states, some reserved and some committed. This means that you can release a range of pages without first determining the current commitment state of each page. The entire range of pages originally reserved by the function must be released at the same time.

If a page is released, its state changes to free, and it is available for subsequent allocation operations. After memory is released or decommited, you can never refer to the memory again. Any information that may have been in that memory is gone forever. Attempting to read from or write to a free page results in an access violation exception. If you need to keep information, do not decommit or free memory that contains the information.

The function can be used on an AWE region of memory, and it invalidates any physical page mappings in the region when freeing the address space. However, the physical page is not deleted, and the application can use them. The application must explicitly call FreeUserPhysicalPages to free the physical pages. When the process is terminated, all resources are cleaned up automatically.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS
member.summary: Contains values representing additional data used to process a request using .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_FORCE_REDISCOVERY
member.summary: Forces cached domain controller data to be ignored. When not specified, may return cached domain controller data. If this flag is specified, will not use cached information (if any exists) but will instead perform a fresh domain controller discovery.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE_REQUIRED
member.summary: Requires that the returned domain controller support Windows 2000 and later.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE_PREFERRED
member.summary: attempts to find a Windows 2000 or later domain controller that supports directory service functions. If a domain controller that supports directory services is not available, returns the name of a non-directory service domain controller. However, only returns a non-directory service domain controller after the attempt to find a directory service domain controller times out.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_GC_SERVER_REQUIRED
member.summary: Requires that the returned domain controller be a global catalog server for the forest of domains with this domain as the root. If this flag is set and the DomainName parameter is not null, DomainName must specify a forest name. This flag cannot be combined with the or flags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_PDC_REQUIRED
member.summary: Requires that the returned domain controller be the primary domain controller for the domain. This flag cannot be combined with the or flags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_BACKGROUND_ONLY
member.summary: If the flag is not specified, this function uses cached domain controller data. If the cached data is more than 15 minutes old, the cache is refreshed by pinging the domain controller. If this flag is specified, this refresh is avoided even if the cached data is expired. This flag should be used if the function is called periodically.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_IP_REQUIRED
member.summary: This parameter indicates that the domain controller must have an IP address. In that case, will place the Internet protocol address of the domain controller in the DomainControllerAddress member of DomainControllerInfo.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_KDC_REQUIRED
member.summary: Requires that the returned domain controller be currently running the Kerberos Key Distribution Center service. This flag cannot be combined with the or flags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_TIMESERV_REQUIRED
member.summary: Requires that the returned domain controller be currently running the Windows Time Service.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_WRITABLE_REQUIRED
member.summary: Requires that the returned domain controller be writable; that is, host a writable copy of the directory service, for Windows 2000 and later DCs, or of SAM (for DCs in operating systems prior to Windows 2000).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_GOOD_TIMESERV_PREFERRED
member.summary: attempts to find a domain controller that is a reliable time server.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_AVOID_SELF
member.summary: When called from a domain controller, specifies that the returned domain controller name should not be the current computer. If the current computer is not a domain controller, this flag is ignored. This flag can be used to obtain the name of another domain controller in the domain.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_ONLY_LDAP_NEEDED
member.summary: Specifies that the server returned is an LDAP server.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_IS_FLAT_NAME
member.summary: Specifies that the DomainName parameter is a flat name. This flag cannot be combined with the flag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_IS_DNS_NAME

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_RETURN_DNS_NAME
member.summary: Specifies that the names returned in the DomainControllerName and DomainName members of DomainControllerInfo should be DNS names. If a DNS name is not available, an error is returned. This flag cannot be specified with the flag. This flag implies the flag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.Netapi32NativeMethods.DSGETDCNAME_FLAGS.DS_RETURN_FLAT_NAME
member.summary: Specifies that the names returned in the DomainControllerName and DomainName members of DomainControllerInfo should be flat names. If a flat name is not available, an error is returned. This flag cannot be specified with the flag.
